sp.p: My Lord Stafford, you ſay you can be ready to mor • ow at Ten a Clock, Are you ſure you can be ready then?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I ſay, my Lords, this, I shall not be ſo ready as I shall be next day; but I aſſure your Lordships, I will rather ſink down in the place where I am, if you think fit, than put off the Tryal.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Look you Gentlemen of the Houſe of Commons, in a Caſe of this conſequence, and of this Vital Importance to a Man as this is, where is the inconvenience if there should be a days reſpite, and the Court should Adjourn till Friday, if my Lords be moved in it, I make no direction, but what inconvenience will be in it? Will it not be every way as well?

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, your Lordships does not expect from us to give our conſent to put off the Tryal.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: I ask only what inconvenience it is?

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: Your Lordships are the Judges, and will do as you find it reaſonable; but this I ſay, it is very unuſual, and ſcarce to be Preſidented, that when the Proſecutors have given an Evidence, the Priſoner should have time, a further conſiderable time, to give his Anſwer to it; the Priſoner knows before▪hand the general Scope and Drift of the Evidence; therefore for him to have time till to morrow is a favour; but to have more than that, even a whole day to intervene, is very unuſual.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: If that be all, and the matter depend upon what is uſual, I do venture with my Lords leave, to inform you, that my Lord of Strafford had two days time after the Proſecution to give his Anſwer to what was ſaid againſt him.

sp.speaker: Sir William Jones.
sp.p: That was an Evidence upon Twenty Eight Articles, this but upon Two Heads; and that was after a long Examination of many days.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords I had prepared my ſelf for my Tryal as well as I could, and had written down a few things that I intended to ſay; and I profeſs before God as I am a Man, and as I am a Chriſtian, of all I intended to ſay I have in a manner made uſe of very few words; but as to what I had to ſay upon the Evidence I was forced to lay all aſide, becauſe I wanted theſe Papers; I have not eaten to day, and being forced to lay aſide all that I had written, I shall need a whole day to write; however I ſubmit my ſelf to your Lordships in that matter.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: My Lord, if it be equal to your Lordship, and your Lordship will be as ready to morrow as another day, this Court will be more ready.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I aſſure your Lordships, if your Lordships do give me another day, I will not debate with my Counſel any one thing upon the Papers I have asked.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, will you be pleaſed to make your demand to my Lords, who are your Judges, by what time you will be content to be forecloſed.

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, if you will give me till Friday, I shall be ready to give my Evidence, and I will bring Witneſſes ſufficient I hope to prove my Innocency.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, we do not preſume at all to offer our conſent to what time the Court shall be Adjourned—

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: No, we do not ask your Conſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: And I hope your Lordships will not ask the Priſoners conſent, nor do it by his direction.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: De morte hominis non eſt cunctatio longa.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: But we muſt deſire your Lordships, as we are entruſted by the Houſe of Commons, to Manage this Tryal, to take notice, that as we do not expect your Lordships should take the Meaſures from our Deſires, much leſs do we expect you should do it at the only inſtance of the Priſoner. 'Tis a great advantage to this Lord to chooſe his own time when he will pleaſe to anſwer our Evidence. We do know very well, that in this Caſe there have been Attempts to Suborn Witneſſes, and that we shall prove in due time, and Attempts to deſtroy Witneſſes too; So that there hath been too much time loſt already, and I think to morrow is a very convenient time for him to make his Anſwer. And I muſt obſerve to your Lordships, that the Priſoner hath gained his end of not making his Anſwer this day by raiſing an Objection, which in my Thoughts carried no great weight in it, though when it was made, your Lordships were pleaſed to Adjourn upon it: But ſeeing he hath got his Point of deferring the making Anſwer till to morrow, there can be no reaſon he should gain a further day, ſince the Depoſitions may be ready by to morrow as well as by the next day. And therefore we deſire your Lordships will be pleaſed to go on in the Tryal to morrow.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: You shall know their Lordships pleaſure when they are withdrawn. Is it your Lordships pleaſure that we should Adjourn?

sp.speaker: Lords.
sp.p: Ay, Ay.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: This Houſe is Adjourned into the Parliament Chamber.

div.p: So the Lords withdrew in their Order, and the Commons went back to their Houſe, and Mr. Speaker reſumed the Chair.
A Meſſage was ſent from the Lords by Sir Timothy Baldwin and Sir Samuel Clark.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speaker.
sp.p: The Lords have ſent us to acquaint this Houſe, that they have ordered the Priſoner William Viſcount Stafford to be brought to the Bar in Weſtminſter-Hall to morrow morning at Ten of the Clock.

div.p: And then the Commons Adjourned to Eight of the Clock next morning.

div.head: The Third Day.
Thurſday, December 2. 1680.
div.p: AT the Hour of Ten in the Morning the Lords Adjourned into Weſtminſter-Hall, and returned in their former Order into the Court there erected; and Mr. Speaker having left the Chair, the Commons were ſeated as before: The Court being ſat, Proclamation for Silence was made, and the Lieutenant of the Tower commanded to bring his Priſoner to the Bar, which being done, the Lord High Steward ſpake to him as followeth:

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord Stafford, this is the time appointed to hear what your Lordship hath to ſay in your Defence, and to call your Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, yeſterday my Lord Viſcount Stafford was pleaſed to make mention of an Affidavit of Mr. Turbervile taken before two Juſtices of the Peace, wherein he was pleaſed to ſay there was ſome Amendment made, and ſo indeed we did then acknowledg there was. But he had a deſire to ſee it notwithſtanding our acknowledgment, becauſe he was informed that that which Turbervile ſwore then, differed from what Turbervile ſwore yeſterday. My Lords, at that time we had not the Affidavit, nor was it proper for us to produce it, for indeed it remained in the Juſtice of Peace's Hands that took it; but now that his Lordship may have full ſatisfaction, and not only his Lordship, but alſo all that are preſent at this Tryal. I do inform his Lordship, that the Affidavit is in the hands of a Member of the Houſe of Commons, Sir Will. Poulteney by name, and if his Lordship pleaſe, he may have it produceed, and make what uſe he can of it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: 'Tis extream Honourably and Worthily done of the Houſe of Commons, and my Lord hath no manner of Exception left him.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, if I shall have occaſion to uſe it, I shall call for it; but I would firſt ſay ſomething to your Lordships; My Lords, I firſt give your Lordships thanks, for granting me the liberty to come ſo late to Day, I have had a little ſleep upon it. Your Lordships heard yeſterday, when you had Dr. Oats at the Bar, the firſt thing that he ſaid, as I remember, was to deſire you would be pleaſed to leave him to his own method; I beg of your Lordships the ſame favour, that I may begin with the one or the other Witneſſes, or with matter of Law, as I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: God forbid but you should take your own Method in your Defence.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: In order to which, I deſire firſt Mr. Turbervile may come to the Bar.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you call Turbervile, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I do.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: He is there, what ſay you to him?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I will ask him but one Queſtion, and I hope I shall have occaſion to ask him no more: When was the laſt time that he ſpoke with me?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Mr. Turbervile, I think I hear right, I do not know: My Lord Stafford asks when was the laſt time you ſpoke with his Lordship?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: It was in November 1675.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I have very much to ſay againſt his Evidence; but I hope your Lordships will not think him any Evidence againſt me, or any body elſe. But I deſire your Judgment, whether I be not within the compaſs of the time limited by the Statute.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serjeant Maynard.
sp.p: Expreſs your ſelf, my Lord, for we do not underſtand you.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I cannot ſay more than I do; the time which the Statute limits is ſix months, but this is five years; I deſire the Statute may be read.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Statute, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: The Statute of the 13th. of this King.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: If your Lordship pleaſes you shall have it read, But your Lordship does not obſerve, you are proſecuted and impeached of High Treaſon upon the Statute of the 25th. of Edward the 3d. not upon the Statute of the 13th. of this King, made for the Safety of the Kings Perſon, which limits the Proſecution of ſome Offences to be within ſix months; but the Proſecution for Treaſon may be at any time.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Does your Lordship ſay it may be at any time?

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: This truly does very much ſurpriſe me, though I am wholly ignorant in matters of Law. My Lords, I have ever heard that no man can be proſecuted by that Statute but within ſo many days, in one part of it Thirty Days, in another ſix months; and I deſire your Lordships that the Statute may be read.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: If your Lordship pleaſe, the Statute shall be read; if your Lordship deſires the Clauſe of the Statute of the 13th. of this King, which limits the Proſecution to be within ſix months, that shall be read. But I conceive your Lordship is not accuſed upon that Statute.

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: I beſeech your Lordships, I may know whether I am proſecuted upon the Statute of the 13th. of this King, or upon what other Statute.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What ſay the worthy Gentlemen of the Houſe of Commons; Is my Lord proſecuted upon the Statute of the 13th. of this King?

sp.speaker: M. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Not at all, my Lord▪ he is not proſecuted upon that Statute, but upon the Common Law, and the 25th. of Edward the 3d. which was only Declarative of the Common Law.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: This is a point of Law.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: What is the point of Law.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Whether I can be proſecuted after ſo many days?

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: The Law is very clear. If you were proſecuted upon the 13th. of this King for any leſs Offence than Treaſon, you could not be proſeſecuted after ſix months, but if you be proſecuted for Treaſon either upon the 25th. of Edward the 3d. or 13. Car. 2d. there is no time limited, and God forbid there should.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I beſeech your Lordships Judgment, whether there be not a Statute, I think 'tis in the Reign of Edward the 6th. that ſets the time, after which no man shall be proſecuted for any thing of Treaſon; I deſire a quarter of an hours time to look into the Statute.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What ſay you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, let me read the Statute of Edward the 6th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: We know not of any ſuch Statute.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I will not ſay there is, but I will ſay, I cannot read if there be not.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen of the Houſe of Commons, my Lord does ſuppoſe he hath ſome kind of Objection in Law to make, which he cannot make out of himſelf; will it be amiſs to let his Counſel make and propoſe the Queſtion for him?

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, we rather would have my Lord propoſe the Objection; for your Lordships know, till a matter of Law is propoſed, he cannot be admitted to have Counſel. If he deſires time to recollect himſelf about the Objection, we can't oppoſe it. But we deſire that he may propoſe the Objection, and after if it be any doubt in matter of Law, your Lordships will aſſign him Counſel to be heard to ſpeak to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Franc. Winn.
sp.p: This would be a way for a Priſoner to have the Advantage of Counſel, when they ought not to be allowed; for 'tis but to ſay, he hath ſome doubt which he cannot propoſe himſelf, and ſo let in his Counſel to make Objections for him. If any Queſtion of Law do ariſe, and that Queſtion is ſtated, you will allow the Priſoner Counſel to argue it, but at this rate he may make the like pretences in every part of his Defence, and ſo obtain that Counſel shall manage his whole Defence for him.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p:
I ſuppoſe my Lord does intend an Objection as to the time of the Proſecution, but he does not know how to make it. He ſuppoſes he is proſecuted
after the ſix months, which he thinks is the time limited for the Proſecution. But I pray, my Lord Stafford, will your Lordship take time to recollect your ſelf, and make an Objection fit for Counſel to be heard upon, and you shall have it.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: I beſeech you, I may have the Statute-Book with me, for I have none my ſelf, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: With all our hearts, we do not oppoſe it.

div.p: Then my Lord withdrew into the Room provided for him, and within a quarter of an hour returned.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Say, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I do confeſs I have been very much miſtaken ever ſince I was firſt committed to the Tower: For I did conceive that they would have proceeded, as I thought, I was impeached upon the Statute of the 13th. of this King. I humbly deſire your Lordships Judgment, whether I ought or no, to be proſecuted upon that Statute?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: The Gentlemen have told you already: They proſecute you upon the Statute of 25th. of Edward the 3d. and upon the Common Law.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: And they lay aſide that Statute?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Statute?

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: The 13th. of this King.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What ſay you, Gentlemen, once more?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winn.
sp.p: My Lords, we have declared already to his Lordship, and if my Lord had looked well upon the Articles of Impeachment, he could not have put that Queſtion, but would have found himſelf impeached for Treaſon at the Common Law, declared by the 25th. of Edward the 3d.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: So then they lay that aſide of the 13th. of this King.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: We do not mention any Statute, but we mention the Crime, and that Crime is againſt the Common Law declared by the Statute, to wit, The attempting the King's Death, and the Subverſion of the Government.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, There is no doubt but the attempting the King's Death is a great and hainous Crime, but, my Lords, I do not find that in the Impeachment, there is any Overt Act at all. And whether I shall anſwer to a Treaſon not proved by any Overt Act ſworn by two Witneſſes, I ſubmit to your Lordships. But, my Lords, becauſe your Lordships and the Houſe of Commons, may not think that I propoſe theſe things out of a deſire of delay; if your Lordships pleaſe, it may be ſaved to me with all other points of Law, I will go on to my proofs.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Yes, all theſe things shall be ſaved to you, pray let us hear your Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Since your Lordships hath granted me that, be pleaſed to give me leave to go to my Evidence, and I begin with Stephen Dugdale.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Set up Dugdale.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Will your Lordships pleaſe I may have Pen, Ink and Paper?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: By all means, my Lord.
(Which was given him.)

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordships Stephen Dugdale ſaid, if I underſtand him aright, (and I ask him again) that he knew ſomething of the Plot, 15 or 16 years ago.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What ſay you, Mr. Dugdale, you hear the Queſtion. Did not you ſay you knew of the Plot 15 or 16 years ago?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: I did ſay it, and did explain my meaning in it. I did ſay there was among us ſuch a preparation to be made againſt the King died, of Arms and Money, that neither should be wanting.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: I beſeech your Lordship to ask what proportion of Arms was to be provided.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What proportion of Arms was to be provided?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: I never heard it nominated how many abſolutely. I have heard of ſome Numbers. I heard of late of 30000. that were to be raiſed beyond Sea, what the whole number in England was, I have forgot, but I think I have heard Mr. Gavan, and ſome of the Prieſts ſay, That if there was occaſion, they should have at leaſt 200000 to aſſiſt them, that was of Men, and I ſuppoſe they had Arms as well as Men.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, If this were true which he ſays Mr. Gavan ſaid, that they were 200000, I deſire to know what Men he ment, what Religion they muſt be of.

sp.speaker: Lord High Stew.
sp.p: What Religion were they of that were to come in and help?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: He did not name them at that time, but I underſtood them, and ſo I apprehend the Company would, that they were Roman Catholicks.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſtrange thing that there should be 200000 Catholicks raiſed, when there are not 20 • 00 in England that can bear Arms.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Good my Lord, They might come from beyond ſea, and ſo they might be ſo many Roman Catholicks, though there were not ſo many in England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: And he ſays not they were Roman Catholicks, but he heard ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Treby.
sp.p: There might be ſo many Roman Catholicks, and ſuch as should be with them.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Did he hear 15 or 16 Years that I was one to be among them?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Anſwer that Queſtion: Did you hear then that my Lord Stafford was to be one among them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: I cannot remember it that I did, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Then, my Lords, I make this uſe of it: He tells you of a Plot 16 Years ago, that 200000 Men in Arms were ready againſt the King's death.—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: I did not ſay ſo, my Lords, I deſire I may be underſtood aright.—

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: You ſay you heard ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: I ſpeak as to the number of Men what I heard of late at the Conſults and Meetings within theſe two Years.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: But I ſpeak of 16 Years ago, what Number of Men was there to be raiſed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: My Lords, it was a general word that was amongſt us, That we muſt be provided againſt that time, againſt the Death of the King, but no Number at all.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: This, my Lords, under favour, I conceive does not concern me. He tells you there was ſuch a thing, it might be ſo, or it might not be ſo, I am not concerned in it, then 'tis out of Doors as to what concerns me: I conceive otherwiſe, if the Gentlemen conceive otherwiſe they will ſay ſo. Then, my Lords, the next thing is, How long ago it is ſince I firſt ſpake to him about this Plot, and I beſeech your Lordships he may mention time and place.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: You hear the Queſtion, Mr. Dugdale.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: The firſt time, to my beſt remembrance—

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I beſeech you, my Lords, let us have no remembrance, but let him ſwear poſitively.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: There is no mortal Man can ſwear otherwiſe than according to his Remembrance.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: When a mans Life and Honour, and all he hath is at ſtake, and indeed in Conſequence every man in England is concerned if they ſwear not poſitively, but ſtill ſay as I remember, who can make a Defence?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Mr. Dugdale, Go on and ſay as near as you can, and be as particular as you can, upon your Oath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: That which I can poſitively affirm, is, It was about Auguſt▪ or September (78.)

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He ſaid yeſterday it was in the latter end of Auguſt, or the beginning of September, which are two Months. I beſeech you what does he mean by the latter end of Auguſt, how long before the end of Auguſt?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: How long was it before the laſt day in Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: My Lords, I will not be poſitive, but it was either in one Month, or the other, I did not keep a Diary, or elſe I would give your Lordships ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I beſeech your Lordships he may poſitively ſay whether in Auguſt or nor in Auguſt, or whether in September or not in September.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: I dare not venture to ſwear that, I dare not do it.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Then ſaving my Exceptions to the incertainty of that afterwards, I would ask him what day was it in September that I ſpoke to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I remember one was either the 20. or 21. of September (78.)

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: My Lords, he ſays the 20. or 21. does he ſay that was the firſt time he ſpoke with me?

sp.speaker: Sir Jolm Trevor.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: I beſeech you my Lords, they may not anſwer the Queſtions, but the Witneſſes; they cry No, no.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord, you shall certainly have an anſwer to all the Queſtions you will ask.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: But when I ask they anſwer for them, I would know whether that is the Courſe or no.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do not diſquite your ſelf for any thing that is ſaid about you, you shall have a fair hearing.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: But, my Lords, I cannot but be diſquieted when I hear theſe learned Gentlemen make Anſwers to my Queſtions for the Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Mr. Dugdale, Was the 20. or the 21. of September, you ſpeak of, the firſt time you ſpoke to my Lord Stafford?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: No, my Lords, it was not.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Pray, my Lords, what day was it then I ſpoke firſt to him?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What was the day you firſt ſpoke to my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Truly my Lords I cannot remember ſo well as to tell you.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you remember when my Lord came to Tixal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: I remember one Sunday in particular, but I cannot tell what day of the month it was.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you remember my Lord Stafford at Tixal in company of my Lord Aſton, and Father Evers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you remember that any diſcourſe paſſed between them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Was that before or after the 21. of September?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Both before and after.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, he ſays there was a Conſult at Tixal, where ſuch and ſuch were preſent, and the Kings Death determined, I ask when was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: That was in September, I cannot ſay poſitively the day, but in September, or the latter end of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I muſt acquieſce and ſubmit to your Lordships to do what you pleaſe; but if he does not name times nor places, how can I make my Defence? I deſire he may ſay poſitively within five days of the one or of the other; and, my Lords, I will put it upon that, if he ſay five days before the end of Auguſt, or five days in the beginning of September, which one would think is ſpace enough, that is ten days time.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: My Lords do obſerve how far Mr. Dugdale goes, and that he is no further poſitive than he does expreſs himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I beſeech your Lordships, I preſs this, becauſe it concerns me very much, that he may be poſitive within five days over or under.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: Can you remember whether it were within five days of the one, or of the other?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Truly my Lords, I cannot be poſitive, if I had not made a particular Remark upon that of the 20▪ or▪ the 21. I could not have remembred that; for I did not then intend to reveal the Plot, or elſe I could have given you ſatisfaction in that.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: My Lord, your Lordship hath an anſwer to it, he cannot ſpeak more poſitively to it than he does.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I beſeech you then how is it poſſible I can make my Defence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: My Lords, I kept no Journal: if I had I would be more poſitive.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He ſays it was the latter end of Auguſt, or the beginning of September, I deſire he will ſay whether it was the laſt week in Auguſt, or the firſt week in September.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: He anſwers he cannot tell, your Lordship muſt make what advantage you can of that Anſwer.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I can make no advantage of it unleſs he does ſpeak poſitively to the time. My Lords, I beſeech you, I may know what is the end of Auguſt and the beginning of September?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord, I hear you not.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: If a man ſays the beginning of June I was at ſuch a place, how many days is the beginning, and how many days the end of a Month? How much time will your Lordships underſtand the meaning of that to be? I am concerned extremely in the point of time, for it is that which the whole Buſineſs depends upon, I mean as to this man.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: My Lord, go on with your Evidence, I know not how to give you an Anſwer, what Judgment my Lords will make of it, or how much they will underſtand by it, till they are withdrawn, they obſerve how much you Lordship inſiſts upon it, and will hear what the worthy Gentlemen of the Houſe of Commons will anſwer to it.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, my whole buſineſs with this Fellow is concerned in a poſitive Anſwer to this Queſtion, I give him I think reaſonable time to confine himſelf to.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What ſay you to the 20. or 21. of September, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I shall give a clear Anſwer to that anon; but I am extremely concerned in this to know whether it was in Auguſt or September.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p:
My Lord, if your Lordship be concerned never ſo much at that, the Witneſs can ſwear no more than he can ſwear. He ſays about the latter
end of Auguſt, or the beginning of September; will your Lordship ſtand ſtill for that?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Well then I will go on as well as I can; as for the matter of the 20. or 21. of September, I beſeech your Lordships I may ask Dugdale one Queſtion, whether at the Tryal of Sir George Wakeman, or the Five Jeſuits he did not ſay the Conſult was in Auguſt, if he deny it, I shall prove it.

sp.speaker: Lord High Stew.
sp.p: Mr. Dugdale, my Lord asks whether at the Tryal of Wakeman, or of the Five Jeſuits you did not ſay it was in Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: My Lords, I did name there was a Conſult at Boſcobel in Auguſt, but I do not remember that I did name my Lord Stafford in any Conſult in Auguſt poſitively; but as I ſay now, the latter end of Auguſt or the beginning of September. But I did name that there was a Conſult at Boſcobel in Auguſt, (78.)

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: My Lords, He did ſay I was at the Conſult in Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I did not ſay my Lord Stafford was there, I don't charge him in it, and if any ſuch thing was printed I have wrong done me.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Then he ſays he had nothing to do with me till the latter end of Auguſt or the beginning of September. My Lords, I beſeech your Lordships to ask him whether in Sir George Wakeman's Tryal he did not ſay, he was to receive Orders from me in June or July, when I came into the Country.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did not you ſay at Sir George Wakeman's Tryal, that you were to receive Orders from my Lord Stafford in June or July, when he came into the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſubmit to your Lordship and the reſt of my Lords here, whether when that Queſtion was asked by my Lord Stafford, I did not ſay, That the firſt time I entred into correſpondency with the Conſulters, they told me, my Lord was to come down then, and I should receive Orders from him? I had heard of my Lord Stafford before, but not to enter into any Conſults with him, till he came down, the latter end of that Summer.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: I beſeech your Lordships pardon me, I deſire him to anſwer poſitively, whether at the Tryal of Sir George Wakeman, he did not ſay, he was to receive Orders from me in June or July, when I came into the Country.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you ſay ſo at Sir George Wakeman's Tryal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: I believe I did ſay ſo, for I had it from others, and not my Lord Stafford himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: My Lords, in June or July I was not in the Country.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: He ſays, You were to come down, not that you did come down.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: If you will let him do thus, there is no man ſafe, I shall begin the Tragedy and millions will follow. He ſwore at the Tryal of Sir George Wakeman, or that of thoſe other perſons, That there was a Conſult at my Lord Aſton's at Tixal, where I was one, in Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: My Lords, I did not ſwear ſo; but in Auguſt or September, or one of them, as now I ſwear.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I shall prove it by the Book, and Witneſſes that were there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Then they did me wrong by printing it, for I never ſaid of your Lordship otherwiſe than I do now.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford
sp.p: I deſire my Witneſſes may be called to prove it, for I conceive it is very material. My Lords, does he deny it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I do ſay there was a Conſult▪ at Tixal in Auguſt, but I did not charge your Lordship poſitively to be there then, nor with more than I do now.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: I think you did, and I have witneſſes to prove it. And 'tis impoſſible for any man living to defend himſelf, if perſons shall ſwear as they ſuppoſe, think, or remember. I tell your Lordships, I was not there in all the month of Auguſt▪

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Does your Lordship intend to call any Witneſſes?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I thought I had more Witneſſes than I have. But I have two here, if your Lordships will hear them, that he did ſwear I was at Tixal in Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Who are they?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Daughter Wincheſter for one, and a Lady that is my Kinſwoman for another.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Let them ſtand up, they are not to be ſworn. You don't except againſt them, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: No, let him prove what he can.

sp.speaker: Lady Marchioneſs of Wincheſter.
sp.p: He did ſwear that he was to receive his Orders from—

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladyship is not upon your Oath; but you are under all the obligations of Truth and Honour in the world.

sp.speaker: Lady March. Winch.
sp.p: My Lords, by the Grace of God I will not ſpeak an untrue word.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: We deſire to know this Ladies Name?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: It is my Daughter Wincheſter.

sp.speaker: Lady March. Winch.
sp.p: This Stephen Dugdale, did ſay, at the Tryal of Sir George Wakeman, That he was to receive Orders from my Lord in June or July, when he was to come down; and that my Lord was at a Conſult at Tixal in Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did he ſay poſitively in Auguſt, or in Auguſt and September.

sp.speaker: Lady March. Winch.
sp.p: No, he did not name September.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: My Lords, I might ſay my Lord was to come down then, but not that ever I ſaid he was there but as now.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: But she ſays, you did not name September.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Here is another Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: Who is she, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Mrs. Howard, Daugh • er to Sir George • lount, and married to Mr. Howard, a Kinſman of mine; she is now a Widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Howard.
sp.p: My Lords, at the Tryal of Sir George Wakeman, Dugdale was asked to be poſitive in the Month my Lord Stafford came down. And he ſaid, he came down in June or July; but he ſaid the Conſult was in Auguſt, wherein my Lord Stafford was.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: That Lady likewiſe ſays the ſame, That you would not be poſitive as to June or July; but as to Auguſt you were poſitive that my Lord was there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: No, my Lords, I only ſaid, in Auguſt there was a Conſult, and in June or July my Lord was to come down.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Howard.
sp.p: I do aſſure you we came to that Tryal on purpoſe to obſerve every word he ſaid about my Lord Stafford, and we have kept it in our memories ever ſince.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What do you ſay, Mr. Dugdale, to it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe there was a great many more at that Tryal than theſe two worthy Ladies, and I ſuppoſe ſome of them may remember, I ſaid no more than I do now. I ſaid then, my Lord was to come down at that time, and ſo I ſaid ſeveral times, but not poſitively that he was there till the end of Auguſt or the beginning of September.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I do poſitively averr, here are two Witneſſes, that ſay, he ſwore, I was there at the Conſult in Auguſt. Now it concerns me to prove, that I was not there in Auguſt, ſince he ſaid abſolutely I was there in Auguſt; and I aſſure you I can prove I was not there not all the whole Month. In the beginning of Auguſt I came from London, from my own Houſe; on Tueſday or Wedneſday the 6. of Auguſt, I went to my Lord Bellaſis's, and that night I went to George Porters, the next night I went onwards towards Bath; when I was there I went over and ſtaid with my Noble Lord, the Marqueſs of Worceſter, there I ſtaid two or three days, and I went thence to another place hard by there, and then I came back again to Bath, and went back again afterwards to my Lords Houſe; and the firſt or ſecond of September, I went from my Lords Houſe to London. Then it this be acknowledged, I need ſay no more; if not, I'll prove it by ſufficient Witneſſes: So then I was not there the whole Month of Auguſt, and the beginning of September he ſays he ſpoke with me. I was not there till the 12. of September. Now I beſeech your Lordships how that could poſſibly be the beginning of September. I ſubmit to you, whether then he be a Witneſs fit to be heard, that shall ſweat poſitively what hath no colour of truth in it, I alſo leave to you. And if they object I was not where I ſay I was in Auguſt, I will prove it. And for the 20. and 21. of September, I do own ſomething of that, and I shall prove to your Lordships what it was.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Call what Witneſſes you pleaſe my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Daughter proves when I went out of Town.

sp.speaker: Lady March. Winch.
sp.p: My Lords, it was on a Tueſday my Father went to my Lord Bellaſis, he dined there and then went on to George Porters.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: That I was at Bath I shall call Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord, you should prove when you firſt came to Tixal, my Lord Aſton's.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Will that ſatisfie your Lordship?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Me; 'Tis not me you are to ſatisfie, but my Lords, and the Gentlemen of the Houſe of Commons.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Then I do own to your Lordships, I came the firſt time the 12th. of September to Tixal.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: That was the firſt day you were there?

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: That Year, my Lord, it was.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: Prove it.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Does he deny that, my Lords?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you deny that my Lord came firſt to Tixal the 12. of September? Or do you know he was there before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: My Lords, I have poſitively ſpoke to no day, but only to the 21. or 20. of September.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Where is my Lord Marqueſs of Worceſter's Servant?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord Stafford, it will be beſt for your Lordship to produce all the Witneſſes you have, and not to leave any thing undone that you can prove.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: But I beſeech your Lordships, I may ask one Queſtion, if I shall name any of the Houſe of Peers as my Witneſſes, does that exempt them from being Judges?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: No, my Lord. If your Lordship have any Witneſſes among any of my Lords here, they may very well teſtifie for you, and yet remain ſtill in the capacity of your Judges: for my Lord of Strafford had a great many Witneſſes that were Peers.

sp.speaker: Sir John Trevor.
sp.p: We do not oppoſe it, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord call your Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford
sp.p: There is no place appointed for them, and therefore I could not have them ready here; I have ſent for them; I have a throng of them.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: They will open the way, and we will ſtay for them.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I deſire, that as Yeſterday, when the Witneſſes were ſworn againſt me, mine did not hear what they ſaid, ſo I deſire when my Witneſſes come, theirs may not be preſent.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord, with your Lordships Pardon, it was not well done that your Witneſſes were not there; but if Witneſſes be to confront one another, shall they not hear what one another ſay?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I am ſo clear in every thing, I will diſpute no little matters.
Then my Lords Witneſs ſtood up.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: What is this mans name you call now, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Indeed my Lord I▪don't know.

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: My Name is Bonny, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Does your Lordship call this man?

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: You are not upon your Oath, but you are to look that a ſtrict account will be taken of what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Foley.
sp.p: My Lords, we deſire to know where this Witneſs lives?

sp.speaker: Bonny.
sp.p: I live in Exeter-ſtreet, by Exeter Exchange.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: I declare it, I know him not, but I am told he can witneſs for me.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Your Chriſtian Name?

sp.speaker: Bonny.
sp.p: Thomas.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Profeſſion are you of?

sp.speaker: Bonny.
sp.p: I live as Clerk of the Kitchin to my Lord Marqueſs of Worceſter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Foley.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Bonny.
sp.p: A Proteſtant, one of the Church of England.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: My Lords, I humbly move your Lordships, When I asked Mr. Smith the firſt day, where he was made a Prieſt, a Gentleman ſaid, he was not bound to anſwer any thing againſt himſelf that might make him Criminal. I deſire that the Queſtion may not be put to my Witneſſes what Religion they are of.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: The Gentleman will not offer to ask any Queſtion that may make a man accuſe himſelf; but my Lord, a Papiſt or not a Papiſt is not ſo penal as a Prieſt or no Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Foley.
sp.p: To acknowledge a mans ſelf a Papiſt, is not to make him a Criminal.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What does your Lordship call this Witneſs for?

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: To prove when I was at my Lord Marqueſs of Worceſters.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What ſay you, when was my Lord Stafford at my Lord Marqueſs of Worceſters?

sp.speaker: Bonny.
sp.p: In Auguſt (78.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you remember it perfectly?

sp.speaker: Bonny.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What day of Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Bonny.
sp.p: The 17. of Auguſt, which my Lord Marqueſs keeps as his Wedding Day every Year, and the Gentlemen of the Country are invited thither. My Lord Stafford was then at Bath, and my Lord Marqueſs was pleaſed to ſend his Coach for him to be preſent there that day; there he ſtaid that day and the next day, and then returned on Monday. And in the ſame month, the 31. of Auguſt, my Lord came again from Bath to Badmin • on, my Lord Marqueſs of Worceſter's, and upon the Monday after returned for London.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: That was the beginning of September?

sp.speaker: Bonny.
sp.p: Yes, the 2. he went to London.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Will you ask him Genlemen any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Managers.
sp.p: No, my Lords.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: Call another Witneſs then. (who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What is this mans Name?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: Thomas.

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: Thomas White.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Thomas what?

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Where do you live?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p: I live with my Lord Marqueſs of Worceſter at Badminton.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What do you ſay?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p: My Lords—

sp.speaker: Lord Marqueſs of Worceſter.
sp.p: My Lord Steward, I have only this to ſay▪ my Lord Stafford deſired that his Witneſſes might not be asked what Religion they were of, but I deſire all my Servants may be asked, for I keep none but Proteſtants.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p: A Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I did not require it for them; I know my Lord keeps none but Proteſtants, but I asked it for others of my Witneſſes, that may come and be ſtartled at it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What ſay you, when was my Lord Stafford at my Lord Marqueſs of Worceſter's Houſe?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p: The 17. of August (78.) I fetched him from Bath, being my Lords Wedding day.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: You fetched him?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What place do you ſerve my Lord Marqueſs in?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p: As Coachman.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Was he there afterwards?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p: Yes he was, but I can't remember the day, only this being a remarkable day I can remember it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you carry my Lord from thence towards London?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p: The ſecond of September to the beſt of my remembrance.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Will you ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Managers.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I think this is ſo clear, I shall not need to trouble your Lordships further with more Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Call whom you pleaſe, my Lord, and as many as you think fit, they shall be heard.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: One more then, my Lords.

div.p: (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. High Stew.
sp.p: What is your Name?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: Richard Bevan.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Who do you live with?

sp.speaker: Bevan.
sp.p: I am Groom to my Lord Marqueſs of VVorceſter.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Bevan.
sp.p: A Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: Do you remember when my Lord Stafford was at the Marqueſs of Worceſter's Houſe?

sp.speaker: Bevan,
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: What time was it?

sp.speaker: Bevan.
sp.p: The 17. of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: Do you remember any other day?

sp.speaker: Bevan.
sp.p: No, my Lord, but he was there that day.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Will you ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Managers.
sp.p: No, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, if your Lordships pleaſe, I deſire my Lord Marqueſs of Worceſter may tell your Lordships, whether his men have ſaid true or no.

sp.speaker: Lord Marqueſs of Worceſter.
sp.p: My Lords, I do remember, that my Lord Stafford was pleaſed to do me the Honour, to come upon my Wedding day from the Bath, and dine with me, as moſt Perſons of Quality that are of my acquaintance, and happen to be at the Bath at that time, are pleaſed to do. And as moſt of the Gentlemen of the Countrey, within ſuch a diſtance do alſo. (And that day is the 17. of Auguſt) I think he was there once or twice after, from the Bath, but I cannot tell preciſely the days; but that particular day I remember, becauſe it was my Wedding day.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Can your Lordship remember when my Lord Stafford went to London?

sp.speaker: Lord Marq. of Worceſter.
sp.p: Truly I cannot tell that, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Did you not after that, lend my Lord your Coach?

sp.speaker: Lord Marq. of Worceſter.
sp.p: Yes, I did, to carry him as far as Sandy-lane, on the Road to London; but the particular day I remember not; but one of the perſons examined (who was then my Clerk of the Kitchin) muſt needs know, becauſe he books every day, who is in the Houſe, and therefore I believe what he has ſaid is true.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Stephen Dugdale I deſire may come again. I conceive I have made it plain to your Lordships, That Stephen Dugdale did ſwear, that in Auguſt there was a Conſult at my Lord Aſton's, where I was, and I conceive it is alſo clear that in Auguſt I was not there; and then if it were the beginning of September, that could not be neither, for I came not down to Tixall till the 12. I beſeech you to ask him when I offered him the Five Hundred Pounds to kill the King, I think he ſays it was the 20. or 21.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: What was the time my Lord offered you the Five hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: It was about that time, the 20. or 21. of September to my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: He ſaid poſitively before, it was one of thoſe two days, I beſeech your Lordship to ask him where it was?

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Where was that offer made?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: In my Lords lodging chamber at Tixall.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Then one Queſtion more, I deſire you Lordship to ask him, what day the Race was at Etching-Hill, between Sir John Crew's man and Lazinby?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: If it pleaſe your Lordship, I do conceive it was about that time.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I pray he may anſwer poſitively, for if you pleaſe I will tell you how it was. It is very true the 20. of September this fellow was in my chamber, and I shall trouble your Lordships with ſome little diſcourſe about it, and my reaſons why: Firſt, I beſeech your Lordships to permit me to let you know, that this fellow did ſerve my Lord Aſton in the quality of a Bailiff. And I never thought him to be an honeſt man, he was a mean Servant, and when the other Servants waited but till the ſecond Courſe came in, he ſtaid till the Coach-man and the Groom went to Dinner, and eat with them. I profeſs before God it is true as that the Sun shines, I have often and often, I cannot tell how many times, when I have been very dry at my Lords Table, and ſeen him by me, not called for Drink, I did deteſt him as ſo mean a Knave, that I often refuſed to take Drink at his hands. And now for me to offer this f • llow five hundred pounds—

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: I think your Lordship ſays he was Bailiff to my Lord Aſton.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: But I knew him to be an errant Knave, and a great Gameſter at Races and ſuch things.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: My Lord, would you have offered five hundred pounds to an honeſt man to kill the King?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: You ſaid you never ſaw him.

sp.speaker: S. Stafford.
sp.p: I ſaid I had ſeen him, but now I did not know him by his Peruke.

sp.speaker: Lord High Stew.
sp.p: Did you not know him, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: No, my Lords, I profeſs I did not.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Why your Lordship was a going to shew that the Race at Etching-Hill was upon the 2 • . of September, and your Lordship confeſſes, that he did ſpeak with you on the 20. of September in your chamber; and Dugdale ſays, this day was the very offer made him of five hundred pounds to kill the King. What do you ſay Dugdale, were you at the Race?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, I was with my Lord at the Race.

sp.speaker: Lord High Stew.
sp.p: Did my Lord ſpeak with you before he went or after?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Before.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: That morning in his chamber▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, it was that very morning, before he went to the Race.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I do own, my Lord, thus far, he was in my chamber that morning; but, my Lord, I can prove what I ſay to you. My Lords, that 20. of September in the morning, I was in my bed, and there comes a Servant of mine that hath ſerved twelve or fourteen years, and he comes in to me, and ſays, Yonder is Stephen Dugdale very deſirous to go to this Race; it ſeems he ſays he went along with me to this Race.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: I ſay I went either before or after, or when you went to the Race, for I was with you at the Race.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Whether he went with you, or no, is not the point, but whether he was in your chamber at that time.

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: 'Tis the point, for he ſaid juſt now, he went with me, as I apprehended him. But I tell your Lordships, my Servant came and told me, Stephen Dugdale deſires that you will ask my Lord Aſton leave that he may go before to the Race, my Lord is angry with him already for his medling in Races, and he dare not ask himſelf. My Lords, I was a little concerned in the Race, for I had betted ſome money, and I thought with my ſelf, should I ask my Lord Aſton leave for him to go▪ my Lord will not deny me, but perhaps will take it ill to be asked; ſo I was not over willing to do it. But I bid my Servant call him in, and when he came, I asked him ſome foolish Queſtions about the Race, as who he thought would win, and the like; but I told him I would get leave of my Lord for him. My Lords, I did go to my Lord Aſton, and told him, My Lord I am ſending my Servant before to the place of the Race, but I am afraid he does not well know the way, shall Stephen Dugdale go along with him? My Lord gave him leave to go; but, my Lords, I dreſſed me, and did not ſpeak one tittle more to this Dugdale, but he went away before, and I was hardly or but juſt dreſt when he was gone.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: I pray, my Lord, was your Lordship at no time alone with him in your chamber?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: No, never ſince I was born, never in all my life.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: No, my Lord!

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He ſays my Servants uſe to come for him, I profeſs it is all falſe.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: What ſay you to that, Mr. Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: My Lords, I was in my chamber, and buſie when my Lord ſent for me that morning; and it was either by his Page or one that waits on him in his chamber; I went to my Lord, and the Page was in the chamber, and he ordered him to go out.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I declare and averr to your Lordships he was in the Hall or the next room and deſired to come in.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: Where is the Page?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: This fellow was but a poor Boy found at the Door, then he was a Thresher, and now a Witneſs for the King.

div.p: (Then my Lord Stafford's man ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What is your Name?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: My Name is Furneſe.

sp.speaker: Lord High Stew.
sp.p: Do you remember the day of the Race at Etching-Hill?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: Yes, I do, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you remember Dugdale was in your Lords chamber that morning.

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you remember whether your Lord did bid you go out or no?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: No, he did not.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Were you there all the while Dugdale was there?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords, I was.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Pray, my Lords, ask him whether I ſent for Dugdale, or he deſired to ſpeak to 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Did my Lord ſend for Dugdale, or did he come to you to ſpeak to my Lord for him?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: No, Dugdale ſpoke to me firſt.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What did he ſay to you, pray?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p:
My Lords, about eight or nine of the clock in the morning, I came to go to my Lords Chamber, and I came through my Lord Aſton's Hall, and coming through, I met Mr. Dugdale coming to me, and ſaid, he had one favour to deſire of me. He ſaid, he would fain go to the Race, but, ſaid he, I do not know how to go, for my Lord is very angry with me, and if I should ask him, he would be worſe, for he is diſpleaſed that I have medled ſo far in theſe matters already: Therefore I deſire ſome means may be uſed that I may go, and I deſire that you would ſpeak to my Lord, to get leave for me to go; for Mr. Fox is there, and hath a great deal of money in his hands, and divers people will give mony to bett; and ſo it will be a great loſs and prejudice to me not to go. So I did promiſe him, my Lords, and went into my Lords Chamber, and told him; and when I had ſpoke to my Lord, my Lord bid him come in, and when he came in, my Lord asked him ſeveral Queſtions about the Race; my Lord asked him what hopes he had, for he ſaid, a great deal of money was laid by ſeveral people; he replyed, he could win, but he wanted money to bett; ſays my Lord, I will bett Twenty pound for Staffordſhire ſake though I were ſure to loſe. And then after ſome diſcourſe to that purpoſe, my Lord told him, he would ſpeak to his Lord. After my Lord was dreſt, he went out of his Chamber, and went to my Lord Aſton, to ask him leave for Dugdale; and my Lord bid me make my ſelf ready to go to the Race. About nine or ten of the clock I was ready to go, and coming down the back ſtairs, my Lord met me; go, ſays he, to Etching-Hill, and ſee what Bets there are, and take Stephen Dugdale with you to shew you the way, for I have asked his Lord leave for him to go. So Stephen Dugdale went along with me to the Stable, and took out his Horſe; mine was not ready, but I overtook him in half a mile, and it was eleven of the clock ere we were at Ridgley. I asked ſome queſtions about one Mr. Gerard; and I think about Twelve of the Clock we were at the Race, and I ſtaid till One with him, and Mr. Fox, who was a party concerned in the Race, and there were ſeveral Betts laid; I was watchfnl when my Lord should come, leſt he should want me: So I left them, and went to the Room where my Lord was to dine; and when I went to my Lord I left him betting. About 2 of the Clock the Lords and Gentlemen all went to Dinner (that were there) and when we had half dined,
betwixt two and three, Dugdale came in, and we ask'd him how the wagers went? he ſaid he would bet Gold to Silver if he had it, but he had betted away all his Money. I know not how much. So there was a Gentleman that was Servant to my Lord Aſton, one George Hobſon by name, he lent him two Guineys and odd Money, and I lent him ſome forty or fifty Shillings out of my own Pocket, which I told him I would not lend unleſs he would give it me at the Hill again, before the Race began, becauſe I was fearful my Lord should go to Stafford again, from my Lord Aſton's that night. About 4 or 5 a Clock I went up to the Race, and demanded my Money, and he paid it me before the Race begun, and after the Race was done I loſt him. My Lord went home, and I waited on him. This was about 5 or 6, and about the mid-way towards my Lord Aſton's Houſe he went into the Coach, and I got on Horſeback, and we got home about 6 or 7 of the Clock as I ſuppoſe. But at night after Supper I enquired for Dugdale, how he took his looſings, and how he did after it? They told me he was gone to Bed, ſo I ſaw him no more that night. The next morning my Lord bid me come betimes, for he would go to Stafford that morning, where we dined, at Mr. Abden's, and from thence took our way to go to my Lords own Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Now, my Lords, if you pleaſe to ask this Boy, whether I bid him go and call Dugdale to me, and leave him there.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord Stafford did bid you, Mr. Furneſe, go and dreſs your ſelf, and make you ready for the Race, did you not leave Dugdale behind you in the Chamber when you went to dreſs your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: No, my Lord, Dugdale was gone thence, and my Lord was gone too, before me to my Lord Aſton's

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: I ſtill ask you the Queſtion, (you are upon an Obligation very great, as much as if you were upon your O • th) whether you were in my Lords Chamber before Dugdale came in, and ſtaid till after he went out?

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: And whether I bid him go out or no?

sp.speaker: Lord High Stew.
sp.p: Were you there before Dugdale went in?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: He went along with me in, I conducted him in.

sp.speaker: Lord High Stew.
sp.p: Did you ſtay all the while Dugdale was there?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: As near as I remember I ſtaid there all the while.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Ask him poſitively,

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords, I was there all the while Dugdale ſtaid, but I cannot ſay poſitively how long it was.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Mr. Dugdale, you are upon your Oath, he ſays he came in along with you, and you went out of the Chamber before him, and he was there all the while you were there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: My Lords, I am not poſitive which of my Lord's Servants it was that came for me, but one it was. But when I came into the Chamber to my Lord, my Lord was getting up, and he charged them both to go ſorth, and the Room was clear, and I ſaw no body.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford,
sp.p: My Lords, ask my man.

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: My Lord never bid me go forth that day, nor any elſe in my life when any was in the room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: My Lords, if it pleaſe your Lordships, Mr. Furneſe was pleaſed to ſay, I would bett Gold to Silver, but in that he was miſtaken, for the odds was quite ſix to four againſt us.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Well we are not upon the Race now, or the Wagers laid there. But, Gentlemen of the Houſe of Commons will you ask this man any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: No, my Lords, we have none to ask.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Lee.
sp.p: We deſire to know where he lives now, what Country-man he is, and what Religion he is of?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Whom do you ſerve now?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: My Lord Stafford.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you live with him ſtill?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: Yes, I do, and have done this fourteen years.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Country-man are you?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: A Dutch-man.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Where born?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: At Bruſſels.

sp.speaker: Sir Franc. Winn.
sp.p: We would ask him what Perſwaſion or Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: You may be ſure of what anſwer you shall have.

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: That is as good as a Jew.

sp.speaker: Mr. Treby.
sp.p: The Queſtion is not intended for any harm, not with any purpoſe to criminate him, 'tis only in regard of his Credit in this matter.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Call another Witneſs, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Where is George Leigh?

div.p: (Who ſtood up)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: How old are you?

sp.speaker: Leigh.
sp.p: I am about fifteen or ſixteen.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I believe he is eighteen or nineteen.

sp.speaker: Mr. Treby.
sp.p: Whoſe ſervant is he?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He is my Servant, he hath ſerved me ſeven or eight years.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What does your Lordship call him for?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford,
sp.p: To tell you, whether I bid my Servants to go out when Dugdale came in, and whether ever he ſaw Dugdale and I alone.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: George Leigh, How long have you lived with my Lord Stafford?

sp.speaker: Leigh.
sp.p: Seven years the 10. of June laſt.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Why then you were but nine years old when you came to him?

sp.speaker: Leigh.
sp.p: No, my Lords, I think I was not.

sp.speaker: L. High Stew.
sp.p: Do you remember when my Lord Stafford was at Tixall?

sp.speaker: Leigh.
sp.p: I do not remember the month very well.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you remember the time of the Race at Etching-Hill?

sp.speaker: Leigh.
sp.p: I do not remember the day, but I was at it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did Mr. Dugdale come into your Lords chamber that morning?

sp.speaker: Leigh.
sp.p: I do not remember he was there that very morning.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Be pleaſed to ask him, whether ever I bid him go out of my chamber when Dugdale was there.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee Dugdale any other morning in your Lords Chamber?

sp.speaker: Leigh.
sp.p: My Lords, I think not, I am not certain, he was there one morning and it was about a Race, but I am not certain what Race it was, whether it was two Boys ran or two Men.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Did your Lord bid you go out of his Chamber?

sp.speaker: Leigh.
sp.p: No, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Dugdale ſays, I often ſent him for him, pray ask him that Queſtion.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord, this Boy does not remember that Dugdale at all was at your Chamber that time of the Race at Etching-Hill; ſo that it is not material to the thing in queſtion.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords, Dugdale told your Lordships yeſterday, that I ſent this Boy often for him.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did ever this Boy come for you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Yes, he hath I am ſure come to my Chamber for me to go to my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Were you ſent for by my Lord more than once?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Yes, ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Before or after the Race?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Both before the Race and after the Race.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: By whom were you ſent for?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Sometimes by the Gentleman that was laſt examined, and ſometimes by this Boy.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you ever come from my Lord Stafford to bid Dugdale come to him?

sp.speaker: Leigh.
sp.p: My Lords, I do not remember that ever I did.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: 'Tis an hard thing to remember ſo long.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford,
sp.p: If ever he came once to me, and was alone with me, I will be content to acknowledge all this to be true. Pray ask the other man, if ever I ſent him for him.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: He did teſtifie before, that he came with him that day to your Lordships Chamber.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: That day, my Lords, But he ſays other days I ſent for him.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Call Furneſe again. (Who ſtood up.) Furneſe, did my Lord Stafford ever ſend you for Dugdale, either before or after the Race?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: Never, my Lords, to his Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lord High Stew.
sp.p: Did he ever in his life ſend you to Mr. Dugdale to ſpeak with him as you remember?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: Never, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He was, my Lords, ſuch a Fellow I could not endure he should come near me, ſuch an Impudent lying Fellow.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Have you any more Witneſſes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Yes, a great many.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Call them all, I pray.

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I hope you think I would not be ſo great and impudent a Fool to employ ſuch a Fellow as this, who not long after run away from my Lord Aſton's.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Who did?

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: Stephen Dugdale. And for that, if you pleaſe, I would call ſome Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Call Furneſe again. (who ſtood up.) Did you ever ſee Dugdale and my Lord Stafford together?

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: Never in my life.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Why, you ſaw them together that morning you brought him to the Chamber.

div.p: [Then the Auditory laughed.

sp.speaker: Furneſe.
sp.p: Never alone.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I did not think I was in a Cock-Pitt, or a Play-Houſe. But if your Lordships pleaſe to let me call my Witneſſes to prove, That Dugdale ran away from my Lord Aſton, I shall call for that Thomas Sawyer.

div.p: (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What is your Name?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: Sawyer.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Your Chriſtian Name?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: Thomas.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Who do you live withall?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: My Lord Aſton.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Where do you live?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: At Tixall.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Are you my Lord Aſton's Servant?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: How long have you been ſo?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: Six years and ever ſince Michaelmas.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What have you to ſay?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: As to Dugdale's reputation, I have this to ſay, How that he went from my Lord Aſton's for debt, and was taken by the Watch at Heywood.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: The latter end of November or the beginning of December.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What Year?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Then the Family broke up.

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p:
And coming thither, and being taken by the Watch, he was brought by the Juſtices to Tixall; and after the Juſtices had been with my Lord, their reſolution was, to carry him to the Gaol. So coming to Tixal where Dugdale was, at an Ale▪houſe, he deſired me to go to my Lord, and deſire him that he would own him as his Servant, for he was ſo much in debt that he should elſe be undone for ever. In the mean time Mr. Philips the Parſon of the Town had been with my Lord (for Dugdale had deſired him to go to him alſo) and he asking me whither
I was going, ſaid I, I am going to my Lord, from Dugdale, to deſire him to own him as his Servant, ſaid he, I have been with my Lord juſt now, and he ſaid, he will not own him as his Servant; it was his own act and deed. So Mr. Philips and I came back to him, and told him. So he ſat down in the Chair, and then roſe up again, and ſwore, He would be revenged of my Lord Aſton if ever it lay in his power.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: You never heard him ſay, he would be revenged of my Lord Stafford, did you?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: No, of my Lord Aſton. Then another time, being at Stafford, he owed me Twenty nine Pounds, and he was under the Serjeants hands, and then he promiſed me from time to time he would pay me, and did not keep his word. This was three or four days before he begun to peach. He bid me come ſuch a day, and he would pay me part of the money; and when I came thither, he told me, it was reported, That he should be a Peacher; and that there was a ſpeech, how that he should have two hundred pounds for informing, that there were Fourteen Prieſts in the Country; but he takes a Glaſs of Drink, and Thomas, ſays he, by God, I wish this may be my Damnation and my Poiſon, if I know of any Plot, or any Prieſts.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Was not he a Papiſt then?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: I cannot abſolutely tell that, whether he was or no.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Do you know one Father Evers?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: My Lords, I have ſeen him.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: Hath he never been at Tixal?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: Yes My Lords, I have ſeen him there.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: And have not you ſeen Dugdale in his Company?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: Yes I have.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did not you at Tixal think Dugdale a ſtout able Fellow?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: No, he never was accounted to be ſo.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Then I ask you, if you thought him an honeſt man, or a rich man?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: No, my Lords; for I'll tell you more than that, my Lord Aſton employed him to be his Bayliff, and receive his Rents, and to pay Workmen their Wages, which he received every Saturday; aud my Lord Aſton did Accompt with him, where he did ſet his hand to receive the poor Workmens Wages according to their Bills, when they had not been paid ſome of them whole years, and half years, and quarters. And they came and cryed to my Lord, that they were not paid; and thereupon Dugdale did ſay, That one of them had demanded more of my Lord than was his due; for he ſaid he had reckoned ſuch a day with him, and paid him ſo much money; which man ſaid he was not that day at Tixal, and ſo he hindred him of part of his money.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you ever know that Dugdale did forſwear himſelf?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p:
That I do not know, my Lords. I did hear he was concern'd in a
Race, about which there was a Tryal and a Diſpute which had won. (This • have heard by report.)

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winn.
sp.p: Speak your own knowledge, not Reports.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: I ask you; do you remember the day when my Lord Stafford came to Tixal?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: He came on the 12. day of the month.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What, September?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: Yes, the 12. of September.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee Dugdale in the Company of my Lord Stafford, while he was at Tixal?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: No, never in the Houſe, but at the Race, he hath come into the Parlour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Treby.
sp.p: You had Diſcourſe with Dugdale; you ſay he took a Glaſs and drank, and wished it might be his Poyſon. Was not Father Evers that time at my Lord Aſton's?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: Not as I know of, my Lords.

sp.speaker: Mr. Treby.
sp.p: Was he not commonly there?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Treby.
sp.p: If he were, Mr. Dugdale muſt know it; and how then could he take a Glaſs and wish it were Poyſon if he knew where any Prieſt was, ſince it was apparent he knew where that Prieſt was? 'Tis moſt improbable Mr. Dugdale should ſay thus!

sp.speaker: Sawyer,
sp.p: My Lords, this was three or four days e're he confeſſed any thing he knew of his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Treby.
sp.p: What Perſwaſion of Religion are you?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: Of the Church of England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Pray, my Lords, ask him one Queſtion; he ſays Dugdale went away from my Lord Aſton's: was not there a ſpeech of a Plot (at that time) that was diſcovered?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: Yes, that I heard.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winn.
sp.p: My Lords▪ I would ask him one Queſtion more: Was there no diſcourſe of the Death of a Juſtice of Peace that was ſaid to be killed in London about that time?

sp.speaker: Sawyer.
sp.p: To my beſt remembrance, as I heard, there was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: My Lords, if your Lordships pleaſe that I should call Witneſſes to confront him now, or afterwards?

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: Not now; ſtay till your time comes.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Then call Philips. (who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew▪
sp.p: What is your Name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: Ralph Philips.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What are you, a Clergy-man?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Are you beneficed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: At Tixal, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: You are a perſon that knows the Obligation that lies upon you to give a true Teſtimony; what can you ſay of Mr. Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: My Lords, I have very little to ſay concerning Stephen Dugdale as to any thing of the Plot, but in reference to what he should relate concerning Mr. Sambidge and me in the Narrative which he depoſed upon the Tryal of Sir George Wakeman: He ſaid then he did receive a Letter concerning the death of Sir Edmundbury Godfrey, which was dated the 12. of October, as I remember; and that he did communicate the Letter to Mr. Sambidge and me immediately the next Tueſday: Whereas I will aſſure you, my Lords, I never heard neither by Letter nor word of mouth from him nor any other, till it was publickly known.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: You did not live in my Lord Aſton's houſe, did you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: No, my Lords.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: We know not what he ſays; we deſire to underſtand what he means.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: He takes notice that Dugdale at the Tryal of Sir George Wakeman did depoſe touching a Letter dated the 12. of October, which should come down to Tixal, intimating the death of Sir Edmnndbury Godfrey, and that he did communicate that with the Parſon of Tixal and another; which Parſon comes now to ſay, He did communicate no ſuch a matter to him.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill. Jones.
sp.p: We deſire to ask him whether he was preſent at that Tryal, and heard him ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: I was not preſent at the Tryal; but if the Narrative of the Tryal be truth, he did ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: So then you only come to diſprove what is printed that Dugdale should ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: Then I leave it to your Judgments, whether what he ſaid in the Narrative of that Tryal, do concur with the Truth.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I deſire then to ask him whether Stephen Dugdale did not run away from my Lord Aſton's, and would have him go to my Lord to own him for his Servant.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What do you know of Dugdale's running away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: I know nothing at all of that, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Whether he did ſpeak to him for his Servant when he was in the Juſtices hands.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Can you ſay any thing touching the Credit of Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: I have nothing to ſay concerning Dugdale's Credit.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you know him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: Yes, ever ſince I came to Tixal?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: How long is that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: About fourteen years.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Reputation had he in the Country? was he looked upon as one that would perjure himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: I never knew any thing of that.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: Was he thought a ſtout man?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: He was in good repute with ſome, and indifferent with others.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Will you call any more Witneſſes, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I would only ask him one Queſtion; Whether he did go to my Lord Aſton from Dugdale, to know if he would own him for his Servant?

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: What ſay you, Sir, did you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords, he knows very well I did; he did requeſt me to go to him. My Lord Aſton I was loth to go to, becauſe I had no familiarity with him, nor Intereſt in him; but he did requeſt and urge me ſo much, that I did go by much motives and perſuaſions from him, and I did ſpeak to my Lord; ſo I told him the Meſſage I had was from Mr. Dugdale, who would requeſt of my Lord that he would own him for his Servant; for if he did not, he knew not what to do with himſelf: but if he did, he might be free from the Gaol and from the Oaths, and eſcape the Troubles that were upon him. So my Lord replyed to me, 'Tis his own act and deed, and I have nothing to do with him, and let the Juſtices do what they will with him; which were Sir Walter Bagott and Mr. Kinnerſley.

sp.speaker: Mr. Foley.
sp.p: We deſire to know whether he heard any diſcourſe about a Plot at that time, or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: Truly, my Lords, I heard a talk of a Plot, but not at that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Foley.
sp.p: My Lords, I deſire to know if he took Mr. Dugdale for a perſon that might be in the Plot, if there was any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Philips.
sp.p: I cannot tell how to anſwer that, 'tis an hard Queſtion; I am not ſo intimately acquainted with perſons whoſe ſecrets are not repoſed in me.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: The next Witneſs I deſire may be (with the leave of the Gentlemen of the Houſe of Commons) Sir Walter Bagott, I did deſire him to be here.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: There he is, we do not oppoſe it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Is it your Lordships pleaſure that Sir Walter Bagott be heard in his place?

sp.speaker: Lords.
sp.p: Yes.

div.p: Sir Walter Bagott.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What would you ask Sir Walter, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: My Lords, I deſire to ask Sir Walter Bagott, whether he did not apprehend Dugdale, and upon what account it was?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Sir Walter Bagott, my Lord deſires to know of you, whether you did apprehend Dugdale, and upon what account?

sp.speaker: Sir Walter Bagott.
sp.p: My Lords, Mr. Dugdale was taken at an unſeaſonable time of night and brought to me the next morning by the Watch, as the other Witneſſes have told your Lordships, and I took him away to Stafford, where there were ſeveral other Juſtices of the Peace; there we offered him the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, which he took. After the taking of theſe Oaths, we told him, that he was a likely man to know ſomething of the Plot, and it was a very proper time for him to diſcover it to us that were Juſtices: he at that time did deny the knowledge of it, that is all I can ſay.

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: I deſire Sir Walter Bagott may be asked whether he did not go to my Lord Aſton, to ſee whether he would own Dugdale as his Servant.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you ask my Lord Aſton to own him for his Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt. Bag.
