sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: My Lords, I had a Letter from his Lordship, which he wrote to me, that he would come by Calice.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He did not name the Letter yeſterday, nor is't in the Information.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Read the Affidavit.

div.head: The Information of Edward Turbervill of Skerr, in the County of Glamorgan, Gent.
div.p:
WHo ſaith, That being a younger Brother about the Year 1672, he became Gentleman Uſher to the Lady Mary Molineaux, Daughter to the Earl of Powis, and by that means lived in the Houſe of the ſaid Earl about three Years, and by ſerving and aſſiſting at Maſs there, grew intimate with William Morgan, Confeſſor to the ſaid Earl and his Family, who was a Jeſuit, and Rector over all the Jeſuits in North-Wales, Shropshire, and Staffordshire: And he, during the three years time, often heard the ſaid Morgan tell the ſaid Earl and his Lady, that the Kingdom was in a high Fever, and that nothing but Blood-letting could reſtore it to Health▪ and then the Catholick Religion would flouriſh. Whereunto the ſaid Earl many times replied, It was not yet time, but he do •• ted not but ſuch means ſhould be uſed in due time, or words to that effect. And he heard the Lady Powis tell the ſaid Morgan, and others publickly and privately, That when Religion ſhould be reſtored in England, which ſhe doubted not but would be in a very ſhort time, ſhe would perſuade her Husband to give 300 l. per annum, for a Foundation to maintain a Nunnery; and this Informant was perſuaded by the Lady Powis and the ſaid Morgan to become a Fryar, the ſaid Lady en • ouraging this Informant thereunto, by ſaying, that if he would follow his Studies, and make himſelf capable, ſhe queſtioned not but he might ſhortly be made a Biſhop by her Intereſt in England, becauſe upon Reſtauration of the Catholick Religion, there would want People fit to make Biſhops, and to do the Buſineſs of the Church, and thereupon she gave this Informant Ten Pounds to carry him to Doway, where this Informant entred the Monaſtery, and continued about three weeks; and with much difficulty made his eſcape thence, and returned for England; for which the ſaid Earl and his Lady, and all the reſt that encouraged him to go to the Monaſtery, became his utter Enemies, threatning to take away his Life, and to get his Brother to diſinherit him, which laſt is compaſſed againſt him. And Father Cudworth, who was than Guardian of the Fryars at Doway, ſome days before his eſcape thence, told this Informant, That if he should not perſevere with them, he should loſe his life and friends. And further added, That this King should not laſt long, and that his Succeſſor should be wholly for their purpoſe. And Father Croſs, Provincial of the Fryars, told this Informant, That had he been at Doway when this Informant made his eſcape thence, he should never have come to England: And this Informant finding himſelf friendleſs, and in danger in England, went to Paris, where one of his Brothers is a Benedictine Monk, who perſuaded this Informant to return for England; and in order thereunto,
about the latter end of November 1675. he was introduced into the acquaintance of the Lord Stafford, that he might go for England with his Lordship, and three weeks he attended his Lordship, and had great acceſs and freedom with his Lordship, who gave him great aſſurances of his Favour and Intereſt to reſtore him to his Relations eſteem again. And ſaid, That he had a piece of ſervice to propoſe to this Informant, that would not only retrieve his Reputation with his own Relations, but alſo oblige both them and their Party to make him happy as long he lived. And this informant being deſirous to embrace ſo happy an Opportunity, was very inquiſitive after the means, but the ſaid Lord Stafford being ſomewhat difficult to repoſe ſo great a Truſt as he was to communicate to him, exacted all the Obligations and Promiſes of ſecreſie, which this Informant gave his Lordship in the moſt ſolemn manner he could invent: Then his Lordship laboured to make this Informant ſenſible of all the advantages that would accrue to this Informant, and the Catholick Cauſe, and then told this Informant in direct terms, that he might make himſelf and the Nation happy, by taking away the Life of the King of England, who was a Heretick, and conſequently a Rebel againſt God Almighty. Of which this Informant deſired his Lordship to give him time to conſider, and told his Lordship that he would give him his Anſwer at Diep, where his Lordship intended to ship for England, and to take this Informant with him; but this Informant going before to Diep, the Lord Stafford went with Count Gramont by Calice, and ſent this Informant orders to go for England, and to attend his Lordship at London, but this Informant did not attend his Lordship at London, but went into the French ſervice, and ſo avoided the Lord Stafford's further importunities in that Affair. And this Informant further ſaith, That one Remige a French woman, and vehement Papiſt, who married this Informants Brother, lived with the Lady Powis all the time this Informant reſided there, and ſome years ſince, and was the great Confident of the ſaid Lady; and the ſaid Remige was for the moſt part taken with her Ladyship into Morgan's Chamber when the Conſults were held there, where he hath often ſeen Father Gavan, Father Towers, Father Evans, Father Sylliard, Roberts, White, Owens, Barry, and the Earl of Caſtlemain, and other Prieſts and Jeſuits, meet and ſhut themſelves up in the ſaid Morgan's Chamber, ſometimes for an Hour, ſometimes for two Hours, more or leſs; and at the breaking up of the ſaid Conſults, have broke out into an extaſie of joy, ſaying, They hoped ere long the Catholick Religion would be eſtablished in England, and that they did not doubt to bring about their Deſign notwithſtanding they had met with one great Diſappointment, which was the Peace ſtruck up with Holland; ſaying, that if the Army at Blackheath had been ſent into Holland to aſſiſt the French King, when he was with his Army near Amſterdam, Holland had certainly been conquered, and then the French King would have been able to aſſiſt us with an Army to eſtablish Religion
in England. Which expreſſions, with many others, importing their confidence to ſet up the Romish Religion, they frequently communicated to this Informant. And the ſaid Morgan went ſeveral times into Ireland, to London, and ſeveral other parts of England, as this Informant hath juſt cauſe to believe, to give and take meaſures for carrying on the Deſign, and the ſaid Remige and her Husband having firſt clandeſtinely ſold their Eſtate, and fled into France about May or June laſt, for fear of diſcovery. This Informant by many Circumſtances, being aſſured that the ſaid Mrs. Remige was privy to all or moſt of the Tranſactions of the Plot. And he ſaith, that about May laſt was two Years, he was preſent at Maſs with the Lord Powis in Vereſtreet, when the Earl of Caſtlemain did ſay Maſs in his Prieſtly Habit, after the Rites and Ceremonies of the Church of Rome.

postscript.p: Sworn the 9th. day of November 1680. before

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: My Lord, this Affidavit is to the purpoſe to which you call for it; this does ſay that your Lordship did go by the way of Calice, it does abſolutely ſo.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Now whether he be forſworn or no, your Lordships may judge by theſe three Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: My Lords, that which I grounded my belief of his going to Calice upon, and ſo conſequently that Affidavit, was the Letter which I received from my Lord, which I have looked for, but cannot find.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: This Affidavit does not ſay you went from Calice to England, but you went with Count Gramont to Calice.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I conceive, my Lords, this Affidavit, and his Narrative are word for word the ſame, only that Amendment of (72) for (73) upon which I obſerved before, he was forſworn once. I cannot tell what to ſay if this man can be believed. And Count Gramont came by Diep too; but beſides, my Lords, in this Affidavit he does not ſay he believed ſo, by the Letter, tho' now he ſpeaks of one.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord Stafford, was Count Gramont in your Lordships company when you came to Diep?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p:
No, my Lords, he was in England before me a month; but, my Lords, I cannot deny, but I had one recommended to come over with me, that
pretended himſelf to be a French Count, but the man was as errant a Raſcal as this that ſwears againſt me, and that was one that called himſelf Count de Brienne, whom all the world knows to be a Cheat.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Call your other Witneſſes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Where is John Minhead?

div.p: (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Who do you belong to?

sp.speaker: Minhead.
sp.p: My Lord Powis.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, Mr. Turbervill, he ſays, by the perſuaſion of my Lady Powis, went to Doway, and he ſtaid in the Monaſtery three weeks, and not liking that life, he came away (this may be true, I ſay nothing to it:) But that which I take Exception at, is this, He ſays, for this the Earl of Powis and his Lady, when he came back from Doway, were very angry with him, and ſo were all his Relations, and he ſtood in fear of his life from them. Surely when Mr. Turbervill knew he was in ſuch danger, he would not have come near them. Pray ask this Gentleman whether he was at my Lord Powis's, and how he was entertained.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Do you know Turbervill?

sp.speaker: Minhead.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Have you ſeen him at my Lord Powis's?

sp.speaker: Minhead.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew▪
sp.p: How was he received there?

sp.speaker: Minhead.
sp.p: Very well, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew,
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Minhead.
sp.p: In the year (75.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Was that before or after he came back to England?

sp.speaker: Minhead.
sp.p: It was after he came from Doway.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Country man are you?

sp.speaker: Minhead.
sp.p: A French man.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Minhead.
sp.p: A Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Pray ask him whether he lay in my Lords houſe.

sp.speaker: Minhead.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords, he lay with me in my lodgings.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: And yet he ſays he was afraid of his life.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did my Lord know he lay there?

sp.speaker: Minhead.
sp.p: Yes, he muſt needs, becauſe he came through the Room to go to Bed.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p:
May it pleaſe your Lordships, he ſays he was threatned that he should have his Brother diſinherit him, and which afterwards was compaſſed. Now I shall shew that this is impoſſible, for he had no Inheritance to loſe, nor was to have none; for his Brother, who is elder than he, this man
being by a ſecond Venter, hath Children, as I shall make appear by another of his Brothers, who is here. And this not being ſettled upon him who was by the ſecond Venter, could not come to him, but for want of Iſſue of that Brother, muſt go to the Uncle. So he ſwears he was diſinherited of an Eſtate when he was to have no Eſtate▪ nor could have. Call Mr. John Turbervill (who appeared.) My Lords, I deſire you to ask him whether he knew that upon his coming back to England, he was ill uſed?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Turbervill.
sp.p: I never knew any unkindneſs from my elder Brother to him.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Are you his Brother?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Turbervill.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords, by the Father, not by the Mother.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Well, what can you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Turbervill.
sp.p: I never heard any thing when he returned from Doway, that he was ill received by my Lord Powis, but in a few days after my Brother and Siſter came to Town, we went to Bloomesbury, and there we met together; and my Brother complaining that he was unfortunate in that he had undertaken what he could not perform in going beyond Sea, and now wanted a Livelihood; my eldeſt Brother told him he had done as far as his Ability was, he could do no more, it was his own Choice, and he had no more to ſay.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: Had he any money from his Relations?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Turbervill.
sp.p: He made interceſſion by Friends to my Siſter, and she told me that she gave him 7 l. to bear his Charges to Paris, with that Proviſo that he would never trouble them more.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: But were they not angry with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Turbervill.
sp.p: Here he is, he cannot ſay they ever gave him an angry word in their days, I'm ſure, I never did.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you not forbid him the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Turbervill.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edw. Turbervill.
sp.p: Theſe are people that take not the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and therefore are not fit to be Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Now your Lordships ſee what a Villain he is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: You muſt give good words, my Lord, for none but good words are given you.

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: I muſt call them Vill • ius, or my ſelf Traitor.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: You ſay they gave him 7 l. upon condition they should never ſee him more.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Turbervill.
sp.p: I did not ſay, my Siſter ſaid upon condition she would give him 7 l. he would never trouble us more, it was his Declaration.

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: One thing I w •• ld ask Mr. Turbervill more, and that is about this man's being diſinherited: Whether he could, or whether he was Heir to any Eſtate or not?

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What ſay you to it?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Turbervill.
sp.p: By all the Information of our Relations, the Eſtate was made by my Grand-father to my Father for life, and after my Fathers life to my Mothers, and after my Mothers life to my Eldeſt Brother, and the Heirs males of his Body; and for want of ſuch, afterwards to me, and the Heirs males of my Body; and in caſe I had none, then to my Fathers Brother, and his Heirs males: and if he had no Heirs males, then after that to the right Heirs of the Grand-father. This was before my time.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Well then, that Remainder to the right Heirs, might come to him; and ſo there was ſome Eſtate for him to loſe, and that Remainder might be docked by the Tenant in Tail. I would ask, Was there any Recovery ſuffered to bar that Intail?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Turbervill.
sp.p: Yes, I think there was one upon my Brothers Marriage.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Mr. Turbervill, Were you told you should be diſinherited?

sp.speaker: Mr. E. Turbervill.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Who told you ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. E. Turbervill.
sp.p: My eldeſt Brother.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What did he tell you?

sp.speaker: Mr. E Turbervill.
sp.p: He told me it should not come to me.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: How should it come to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. E. Turbervill.
sp.p: I am not ſo good a Lawyer as to tell that, whether it could or no, but I thought by Succeſſion.

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: Then he ſays he came to ſerve my Lady Mullineux in (72.) it may be it is ſo as he ſays, I don't know it of my own knowledge; but I pray he may anſwer, whether it was in (71) or (72.)

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Turbervill.
sp.p: In January or February (71.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Treby.
sp.p: That is the beginning of the year (72,) according to the Almanack.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: My Lords, for the preſent I do not remember any thing more—Oh, yes, my Lords, he ſays he was at ſuch a time at my Lord Powis's, when my Lord Caſtlemain was at Powis-Caſtle, which muſt be either in the year (72) (73) or (74.) Now I deſire you would ask Mr. Lydcot whether my Lord Caſtlemain was there, or could be there in any of thoſe years.

div.p: (Then Lydcot ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What do you ask him, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Stafford.
sp.p: I deſire to ask him, whether in the year (72,) (73,) or (74.) which are the years Turbervill ſays he was at my Lord Powis's at Powis-Caſtle, whether my Lord Caſtlemain was at Powis-Caſtle, or could be there at that time.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Was my Lord Caſtlemain there in any of thoſe years?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p:
My Lords, I can prove he was not, as much as I am capable of
proving a Negative. I was with him in the years 72, 73, and 74.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: He was in England in 73. I was with him all the while; and I am ſure ſince I knew him he was never in Wales, and I was never abſent from him ſince I knew him (which is nine years) not four months in all. I have travelled with him, and been abroad with him.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Turbervill, When do you ſay my Lord Caſtlemain was at Powis Caſtle?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: I think it was in the year 73.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: By what Token do you remember him there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: He was arguing with my Lord Powis about Religion, and ſeveral times he did ſo; I believe it was in the year 73.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What ſay you to that?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: I can aſſure your Lordships he was not there then, I was always with him that year; he had many times a deſign to go there, but he could not but put it off, and the laſt time he was there, I can prove it was fifteen years ago.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: I deſire to know of you this, Friend, can you take it upon you to affirm upon the Faith of a Chriſtian, that you were never from my Lord Caſtlemain all the year 73?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: I can give an account to half a week where he was. And when I was abſent from him, it was beyond Sea, and all that while I kept Correſpondence with him every Poſt, and received Letters from him conſtantly once a week dated from Liege.: This was in the time of my abſence.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Were you at Liege when my Lord was in England, or were you with him all the time that he was in England?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: My Lords I was with him all the time he was in England, and was never abſent from him all that compaſs of time, but when he ſent me into England from Liege.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Then he was at Liege himſelf?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Was that in the year 73?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords, I was then in England. But, my Lords, I can give you an whole account, for my Lord and I never made any Journeys, but I put them down.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: You ſay you can give a particular account of the whole year 73. even to the compaſs of four days in that year at moſt.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: No, my Lords, I do not ſay ſo, but I ſay I can give an account of the whole time I have been with him within four months.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Were any of thoſe months within the year 73?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: No, I was with him all the year 73.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Will you take it upon you to ſay, That every day in 73. you were with my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Every day, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Every week?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Yes, I do not think but that I was. My Lord did me the honour to make me as it were his Companion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: No, you do your ſelf the honour to make your ſelf his Companion, he made you his Servant.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Come, where are your Notes you pretend to ſpeak by? your Diary, or your Journal? let us hear a whole account of the year 73. for you come to teſtifie as if you could give an account of every day.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: I did not think any Queſtion of this Nature would come on the ſtage, there is my Lords Steward can give a very good account of this by his Account Books, which are all ready to be produced; he can tell where my Lord was, by laying out ſuch and ſuch moneys. And 'tis an hard thing to give a Teſtimony after ſo many years, of a thing that we thought not would ever be a Queſtion.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Let us ſee your Notes.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: My Lords, I will read it to your Lordships.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: When was this written?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: I took this out of another Book.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Lately, ſince Mr. Turbervill's Narrative came out.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: Oh, I deſire that may be obſerved.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: If your Lordships pleaſe, I deſire that he may bring his Books, Oh, oh, will not condemn me, but Law and Juſtice. I am not to be run down with Oh, oh, or what ſuch impudent Villains as theſe ſay.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Read what you have there.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: From Liege we ſet forth to Paris, January 1. 72. where we ſtaid three weeks, and arrived thence at London January 24. there we ſtaid till May 73. and from thence we went to Liege again in June, and from Liege we ſet forth to London in Auguſt, and returned October the 3d. 73.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Were you all the while between Auguſt and October in London?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: I am morally certain, that I did not go from my Lord all that time.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Where were you after October?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Which October, if your Lordship pleaſe?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: October, 73.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: At Liege, for we returned to Liege at October the 3d. and then after this my Lord ſent me into England. I left him at Liege, and from thence I ſet out for England, and in January I returned to Liege, which was the greateſt part of time that I was ever abſent from him.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: And was he at Liege, are you ſure, all that time from October to January?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Yes, except he fled: For I ſent Letters by the Foreign Poſt, and received Letters by the Foreign Poſt every week. And his Account-Books will ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, we deſire to ask him one Queſtion (ſince he can give ſo exact an account) whether my Lord Caſtlemain was in England (72) and how much of that year?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Jones.
sp.p: How many months of the year (72) was he in England?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: I read it before. We arrived from Liege to London, January 24. (72.) and ſtaid at London till May (73.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: But where was my Lord all the year (72?)

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Pray, my Lords, do you mean New ſtile, or Old ſtile?

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: When I ſpeak of his being at London, I mean the ſtile of the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Sir William Jones.
sp.p: Then under favour, he ſpeaks of the latter part of the year: I deſire to know, whether my Lord for all the former part of the year was in England.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Where was my Lord in December (72.) and in November before that, and in all the year up backwards?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: My Lords, I have told you the whole year.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: But where was my Lord from January 71. to January 72?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: In 71. June 19. New ſtile, we came to London, and returned in September to Liege; from Liege we ſet forth to Paris January 1. 72. and arrived at London January 24.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: He runs paſt the time.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, we ask him a plain Queſtion, but he does not anſwer it; he ſlips over the time that we deſire your Lordships to ask him about

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I beſeech your Lordships that it may be made plain, that there may nothing be ſaid afterwards that it was not plain.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Sir, Do you propoſe any thing to me, and I will anſwer it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: Anſwer not us, anſwer my Lords.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: I deſire any body may peruſe my Notes, if they pleaſe.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, anſwer the Queſtion, whichin very short terms is this, where my Lord Caſtlemain was all the whole year 72.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: Well, my Lords, I will: I can but read it over again. From Liege we ſet forth to Paris, January 1. 72.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Are not you a rare Fellow now?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: My Lords, I underſtand it according to the ſtile of that Country when I am there, and of this place when I am here

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Anſwer me according to our ſtile.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p:
This that I have written here, in the Book out of which I took it,
hath been written ever ſince that time; and I did not think I should er'e be called to account about it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Begin January the 1ſt. 71.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: We went from Liege to Paris, where we ſtaid about a week, or ſuch a time, and we arrived at London, January 24. that is the Old ſtile, and ſtaid at London till May 8. 73.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: That is impoſſible, for you 'ſcape a year and a half to together.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: My Lord was here in England in January.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: You begin very gravely with January, ſtylo veteri, that you came from Liege, and ſo January 24. ſtylo veteri, you came to London.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: When I ſpeak of any ſtyle, I underſtand it according to the ſtyle of the Country.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: But in your account, what is become of all the time from January 71. to January 72. ſay and ſwear, if you can, where my Lord was all that time.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: He muſt be in London.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Can you take it upon your Oath, that my Lord was in London from January 71. ſtylo veteri to May 73. ſtylo veteri?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: I cannot know how to count better than I have done.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Mr. Turbervill. ſays, my Lord Caſtlemain was in 73. at Powis-Caſtle; I beſeech your Lordships this man may be asked, and that without any interruption, where my Lord was that year.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: With your Lordships favour, I muſt deſire your Lordships to ask Mr. Turbervill whether he did ſay poſitively the year • 3. for if my Ears and my Notes do not fail me, he ſaid, As he remembred, and that is the reaſon why we ask about the year 72.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: My Lords, I do not ſay poſitively, nor cannot, which year it was.

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: My Lords, I do ſtand upon it that he was in London January 72. and went away May 73.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What becomes of the mean time, between January 71. and May 73?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: My Lords, I explain my ſelf as well as I can.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew,
sp.p: My Lord Stafford, will you call any more Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Call them then.

sp.speaker: Earl of Shaftsbury.
sp.p: My Lord High Steward, I deſire my Lord Stafford may be asked how many Witneſſes my Lord hath more, for it now grows late.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know how many Witneſſes you have more?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Three or four, I can't well tell how many.

sp.speaker: Lords.
sp.p: Adjourn, Adjourn.

sp.speaker: Lord. High. Steward.
sp.p: Is it your Lordships pleaſure that we do Adjourn?

sp.speaker: Lords.
sp.p: Ay, Ay.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Then this Houſe is Adjourned into the Parliament Chamber.

div.p: Then the Lords returned in their former Order to their Houſe, and the Commons went back to their Houſe.
Mr. Speaker, reſumed the Chair, and a Meſſage from the Lords was ſent by Sir Timothy Baldwin and Sir Samuel Clark.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speaker,
sp.p: The Lords have ſent us to acquaint this Houſe, that they have Ordered the Priſoner William Viſcount Stafford to be brought again to his Tryal at the Bar in Weſtminſter-Hall to morrow morning at Ten of the Clock.

div.head: The Fourth Day.
Friday, December 3. 1680.
div.p: ABout the Hour of Ten in the Morning the Lords Adjourned into Weſtminſter-Hall, and returned in their former Order into the Court there erected; and Mr. Speaker having left the Chair, the Commons were ſeated as before mentioned.

The Court being ſat, Proclamation for Silence was made, and the Lieutenant of the Tower commanded to bring his Priſoner to the Bar, which being done, the Lord High Steward ſpake to the Priſoner as followeth.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p:
My Lord Stafford, your Lordships Defence took up yeſterday; All the day was employed in hearing your Lordships Witneſſes to impeach the Credit of the Teſtimony that hath been given againſt you. Your Lordship hath excepted againſt Dugdale, becauſe you were not at Tixall, as he ſays you were; neither the latter end of Auguſt, nor the beginning of September till the Twelfth; and when you were there, you never ſent for him to your Chamber, but your Man upon his own deſire brought him, and when he came there, the buſineſs was to deſire you to get leave that he might go to the Race; and there was no opportunity of private Diſcourſe, becauſe your Men were in the Room all the while; That Dugdale hath often ſaid he knew nothing of the Plot; that he ſwore falſly when he ſaid he told of the Letter about the death of Sir
Edmunbury Godfrey before it was known he was killed; and when he ſaid, that Hobſon told him preſently after the Almoner went over, which was three years before Hobſon came to my Lord Aſton's Service. Your Lordship hath likewiſe objected, that he hath corrupted perſons to ſwear falſly againſt you, and others, as Robinſon the Upholſterer, againſt your Lordship, Morrall the Barber againſt Sir James Symons, and Holt the Blackſmith to ſwear that one Moor carried away Evers. Your Lordship hath endeavoured to diſcredit Oats, by his ſaying he knew nothing of any other perſons that were concerned in the Plot, and after accuſing the Queen: Your Lordship hath Impeached the Credit of Turbervill, by proving, that you came home by Diep, and not by Calice, as he ſays you did; That you had never the Gout while you were in France, nor, as your Page ſays, for theſe ſeven years; That my Lord Caſtlemain was not at my Lord Powis's in the year 73. and there you left off. This I take is the Sum of what your Lordship ſays, if I do you any wrong, your Lordship will put me in mind of it.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I thank your Lordship, you have done it with great Equity and Truth.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Then go on.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: The next Witneſs that I call, is one John Porter.

div.p: (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What is your Name?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: John Porter.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Profeſſion are you of?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: A Butler.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: To my Lord Powis.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I deſire your Lordships would ask him what Mr. Turbervill ſaid about the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: I will ask him all the Queſtions your Lordship deſires I should ask him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Foley.
sp.p: We deſire to know what Religion he is of?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I deſire your Lordships would ask him that Queſtion, and not the Managers.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: They will tell me their Queſtions, my Lord, and I will ask them.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: They ask him, my Lords, and not you.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: A Church of England man my Lords.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: The Popish Church of England, I believe.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Pray, my Lords▪ let not this be, when my Witneſs ſays he is of the Church of England, they cry he is of the Popish Church of England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p:
Pray, good my Lord, we are ſilent when you ask him
proper Queſtions, and make no Remarks, we do not ſpeak it to the Court, we may ſay what we will among our ſelves, I hope.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: I may ask impertinent Queſtions, becauſe I do not underſtand ſo well as theſe Gentlemen. But I pray they may not deal thus with me.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord, you shall ask what Queſtions you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Pray ask him what Mr. Turbervill ſaid to him about his knowledge of the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What did Turbervill ſay to you about his knowing of the Plot?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: About a year ſince, when I ſerved my Lord Powis, as Butler there, he was uſed to come and ſee me, it was not at my Lords Houſe, but he ſent for me to a Victualling-Houſe—

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: That was the laſt year?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What time of the Year?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: It was about Twelve Months ago, I cannot ſay poſitively the time.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Was it Winter or Summer?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: He hath been both, I can't be poſitive which; I believe he hath been there 40 times.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: In the year (80) or (79?)

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: In the year (79.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: He came there, and asked me how my Lord Powis did, and ſaid he was extremely troubled that he was in that Affliction, for he did verily believe, that neither he, nor the reſt of the Lords were in the Plot, and the Witneſſes that ſwore againſt him, he believed were perjured, and could not believe any thing of it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Have you any more to ſay?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords, I told him if there were ſuch a thing as a Plot, he having been beyond Sea, muſt certainly know of it; he told me, as he hoped for Salvation, he knew nothing of it, neither directly nor indirectly, againſt the Kings Sacred Perſon, nor the Subverſion of the Government. And he further ſaid; Although I am a little low at preſent, and my Friends will not look upon me, yet I hope God Almighty will never leave me ſo much, as to let me ſwear againſt innocent Perſons, and forſwear and damn my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Where was this ſaid to you?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: At the Ship Alehouſe in Lincolns Inn Fields one time, another time at the Kings Head Tavern in the Strand, and another time at the Golden Ball in the Strand.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Was any body by, beſides your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Not at that time, but there is a Gentleman in Court, that can teſtifie that he ſaid ſuch things at other times.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What ſay you to this Turbervill?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: I ſay 'tis all falſe. But if your Lordships pleaſe, I'll tell you what I ſaid once, I did conceive my Lord Powis was the leaſt concerned of any, I thought, and I hoped it would prove ſo. I can take all the Oaths in the world I ſaid no more.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What elſe do you know?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Only ſuch things as theſe he hath often ſaid.

sp.speaker: Earl of Shaftsbury.
sp.p: Pray, my Lords, ask him how came Turbervill to talk of Witneſſes about the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Upon what occaſion came Turbervill to talk of theſe matters?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: It was only voluntary of himſelf, it was ſpeaking of my Lord Powis, and the reſt of the Lords in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Earl of Shaftsbury.
sp.p: My Lords I mean of his own being a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: How came Turbervill to ſay, he hoped God Almighty would never forſake him ſo far, as to let him ſwear againſt innocent Perſons, he was never called to be a Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: But, my Lords, ſome of his Friends did ſay they were fearful of him, in regard he was reduced to poverty; His Friends were fearful.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Who were fearful?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: His Brother and Siſter, Mr. Turbervill and his Wife.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Did he take notice to you that they were afraid he would come in?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Turbervill did tell me himſelf, that they heard he would come in?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Have you ſaid all you have to ſay?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: My Lords that is all I have to ſay.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Then call another, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Where is Mr. Yalden?

div.p: (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What is your Name?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: Yalden.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Your Chriſtian Name?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: John.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What is your Profeſſion?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: A Barreſter at Law.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: How long have you been called to the Bar?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: I was called to the Bar laſt Trinity Term 12 months.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Houſe are you of?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: Grays-Inn.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Are you a Practiſer?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: Of the Church of England.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Well, what can you ſay?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: I am ſummoned to appear by Order of this Houſe, and I deſire to know of my Lord what he is pleaſed to examine me about.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: What Mr. Turbervill hath ſaid in his hearing about the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What Diſcourſe hath paſſed between you and Turbervill about the Plot?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: My Lords, in February or March laſt, I was walking in Grays-Inn-Walks with Mr. Turbervill, and Mr. Powell and he dined with me a day or two after, and there Mr. Turbervill and I were talking of the Diſtractions of the Times, how Trade was ruined, how the whole Kingdom was out of order, and he was a little touched at ſome things, and cryed out, Go! Dam me, now, there is no Trade good but that of a Diſcoverer, but the Devil take the Duke of York, Monmouth, Plot and all, for I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: That is odd, that he should ſay it was a good Trade to be a Diſcoverer, and at the ſame time ſay, he knew nothing of the Plot.

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: This I underſtood to be his meaning; he curſed himſelf and them, becauſe he knew nothing of the Plot to diſcover, for he would have got money by it (as I underſtood) as well as others.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: My Lords, Mr. Yalden did declare yeſterday, he was ſummoned in by my Lord Stafford the laſt night, and that he had nothing to ſay but what was by Hear ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Yalden.
sp.p: My Lords, I do declare what I ſay is true; and yeſterday Mr. Powell gave me a Caution to take heed what I did, and ſwore, by God, it would elſe be the worſe for me.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Who did?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: Mr. Powell.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: Mr. Turbervill's Friend. And I ſaid I do not appear here as a voluntary Evidence, but by an Order of the Houſe of Lords; I do not know what weight my Evidence may have, for I can ſay nothing but what I heard him ſay, and ſo perhaps it will be taken but for an Hear-ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: You ſaid you knew nothing but by Hear-ſay.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Will you ask him any Queſtions Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Managers.
sp.p: No, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I shall not trouble your Lordships with any more Witneſſes as to theſe Points; I have here a Copy of the Warrant for the Yaught to go to Diep; and if there be any Queſtion whether I did come over from Diep at Chriſtmas 75. if you pleaſe the Book may be ſearched.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord it is all loſt, for I hear not one word.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I ſay, my Lords, if it be fit to trouble your Lordships with it, I can prove that I did come over in the Yaught from Diep at Chriſtmas 75. Here is the Copy of the Warrant for it to go for me. And whether you will have it proved that I did come over thence, I ſubmit to you.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe that is fully proved already, that you did come by Diep.

sp.speaker: Managers.
sp.p: We do not deny it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: You do not ſtand upon it, Gentlemen, do you?

sp.speaker: Managers.
sp.p: No, no, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: 'Tis admitted to you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, when I went from your Lordships Bar laſt night, I had no thoughts of examining any Witneſſs, but what I have already done: But, my Lords, ſince I was here, there hath ſomething happened, about which I deſire Dr. Oats may be called again, (I shall give you the reaſon why I move it afterwards,) upon ſomething I heard yeſternight.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Call Dr. Oats again.

div.p: (Who appeared and ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: My Lord, what does your Lordship call him for?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He did ſay, that he being a Miniſter of the Church of England, did ſeemingly go over to the Church of Rome, or ſome ſuch words; I deſire he may anſwer that firſt.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſay, I did but ſeemingly go over.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I deſire to know, whether he was really a Papiſt, or did but pretend.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: I did only pretend, I was not really one, I declare it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What do you make of that?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I deſire to know how long Dr. Oats was in Spain.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, I came into Spain in May, and I came home again in November.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: That is ſix months.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He is called Dr. Oats: I beſeech your Lordships to ask him, whether he were a Doctor made at the Univerſities here, or abroad.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, if your Lordships pleaſe, any matter that is before your Lordships, I will anſwer to it, but I hope your Lordships will not call me to account for all the Actions of my life, whatever Evidence is before your Lordships, I will juſtifie.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: The Doctor hath never taken it upon his Oath, that he was a Doctor, and why do you ask it?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He is called a Doctor, and I would know whether he did never declare upon his Oath, that he took the Degree at Salamanca?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p:
My Lords, I am not ashamed of any thing I have ſaid or done.
I own what is entred as my Oath before your Lordships, and am ready to anſwer it; but I am not bound to ſay, what does not at all concern this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I ſay, my Lords, 'tis entred upon your Lordships Books, that he did ſwear at the Council, he was at Madrid with Don John of Auſtria; I would know of him whether he did ſo.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, I would have my Lord to propoſe the Queſtion to the Court of Peers.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Have you ſworn any thing of Don John of Auſtria?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords▪ I refer my ſelf to the Council Book.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I beſeech your Lordships, I may have that Book.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: I believe it is in the Narrative, turn to the Journal, you have that mentioned there.

div.p: To which the Clerk turned, but it could not be ſound.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: If you will not acknwledge it, we muſt ſtay till the Book be brought.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, if your Lordships pleaſe, I will repeat, as well as I can, what was ſaid at the Council Table, but I had rather the Council Book were fetched, becauſe I am upon my Oath; but, my Lords, I always thought the Council Book is no Record upon any man.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I deſire it may be produced, or he own that he ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord High Steward.
sp.p: What you ſaid at the Council Table, you ſaid upon your Oath, and 'tis lawful to lay it before you.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: But, if your Lordships pleaſe, as to what was ſaid at the Council Table, if my Lord will bring any one Viva voce, to ſwear what was ſaid by me there, that will make ſomething.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: That may be material, as he ſays, That your Lordship should bring ſome body to ſwear he ſaid ſo; for the Clerks may miſtake him.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: If your Lordships pleaſe that the Book may be ſent for, I will make it out.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Jones.
sp.p: It could not be read if it were here.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: If the Clerks will ſwear what is in the Books, it may.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Jones.
sp.p: But whether the Clerks will take that upon them or no, may be Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Lord. High. Steward.
sp.p: Go on in the mean time.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I cannot conclude with him without it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Where is the Council Book? For the Clerks inform me 'tis not in their cuſtody; but the Gentlemen of the Houſe of Commons have been attended with the Book, and other Papers relating to it.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford
sp.p:
In the mean time, give me leave to ſay ſomething; though perhaps
it may be nothing to the purpoſe; Mr. Yalden was juſt now going down' and Turbervill threatned to lay him by the Heels.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: If he did ſo, 'tis a Miſdemeanor, and he muſt be punished for it. Call Yalden and Turbervill.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Mr. Turbervill, Have you dared, or threatned Yalden the Witneſs, to lay him by the Heels?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: I did not ſpeak any ſuch words to him, Mr. Dugdale was juſt by me all the while.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I tell you but what he ſaid, and what I can prove by Witneſs; pray call Yalden.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: This Gentleman, Captain Scudamore, ſtood by me too.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: But I ask you upon this Miſdemeanor, Whether you threatned Yalden to lay him by the Heels?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: My Lords, I ſtood by Mr. Dugdale till he was gone down.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: How could he lay him by the Heels? By what Authority could he do it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: I did not ſpeak ſuch a word, upon my Oath.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Ask Yalden, I am told he did.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: I am afraid you are miſinformed, my Lord, for he could not do it, 'tis not in his power.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He threatned he would Goal him, but if you won't Examine it, I ſubmit to you.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, Yalden, it ſeems, calls us a Pack of Rogues, that give Evidence for the King; and here are Witneſſes of it.

div.p: (Yalden ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Yalden, were you threatned by Turbervill?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: Yes, I will tell you how I was threatned, my Lords, Mr. Turbervill pulls me by the Arm, when I had given my Evidence, and asked me if I knew him, and bid me take care.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you call that a threatning?

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: My Lords, I did not make this Complaint, nor did I deſire it should be made; but ſpeaking this in the Room, ſome body carried it to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: My Lords, now he hath done, let me ſpeak, I pray; Mr. Yalden did ſay in the hearing of Captain Scudamore, who is here, he had got a great many Clients here, but you, ſays he, have got nothing but a pack of Rogues.

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: That is a miſtake.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: This is fine work. But, Gentlemen, will you call Captain Scudamore now, or will you ſtay till afterwards?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winn.
sp.p:
My Lords, Mr. Turbervill deſires it may be now, and we do alſo deſire it upon this occaſion, Captain Scudamore is a man of Quality, and will
give you a true account. We did not think to have interpoſed in my Lord Stafford's Evidence, but he having impeached our Witneſſes of a Miſdemeanor, we conceive it fitteſt to clear it at this time.

div.p: Then Captain Scudamore was ſworn.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Mr. Scudamore, what are you called for? Can you ſay any thing that happened between Turbervill and Yalden?

sp.speaker: Captain Scudamore.
sp.p: The Gentleman that is here, that ſaid he was one of Grays-Inn, I do not know his Name—

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: 'Tis Yalden.

sp.speaker: Captain Scudamore.
sp.p: I heard a Gentleman ask him, if he came there to get Clients? And he ſaid, I know nothing among you but Roguery.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Whereabouts did this Gentleman ſtand?

sp.speaker: Captain Scudamore.
sp.p: In the Paſſage.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervill.
sp.p: Here are five or ſix more that heard him ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: That which I ſaid, was this, That I might come hither for Practice, but I did not come hither for Roguery.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord Stafford, until ſuch time as the Council-Book comes, which may be ſent for: Will your Lordship proceed to ſomething elſe?

sp.speaker: L. Wharton.
sp.p: My Lord Steward, I humbly conceive, That it was reſolved in the Lords Houſe, the day before yeſterday, that no Book should be ſent for out of the Court, and it was done upon the Judgment of all the Judges of England.

sp.speaker: Yalden.
sp.p: My Lords, They will not permit me to go down.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: There is a ſtrange Quarrel between you Witneſſes, and an Affectation of complaining one of another. Let Mr. Yalden go down.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, I would only acquaint your Lordships, that the Council-Book, that my Lord does make mention of, was in the hands of our Clerk, we did not know of it when it was firſt diſcourſed of; but now underſtanding that here it is, we deſire it may be delivered in to any body that hath occaſion for it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Hand it in.

div.p: (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What day does your Lordship ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: The 28, 29, or 30. of September.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Then this is not the Book, for this is for January.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, Is it your Lordships pleaſure I may have Pen, Ink, and Paper allowed me?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Yes, yes, give my Lord Pen, Ink and Paper, (which they did.)

div.p: Then the Lord High Steward looked upon the Council-Book.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord Stafford, In this Council-Book, as far as we can inform our ſelves by the Table of it, there is nothing at all of it; it muſt be the Council-Book in September.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: We have no other Book but that.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Why did not your Lordship ſend all this while to the Council Table for any thing that was material, but give the Court the trouble to be interrupted upon your Inquiries?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, you may do what you pleaſe, I did not know any ſuch thing would have needed to be urged. I have proof enough without the book; The uſe I should have made of it, is this, I do appeal to ſome of your Lordships (you that were of the Council) I do appeal to which of you that were by, whether Dr. Oats did not ſay at the Council Table, he had been at Madrid, he went from Vallidolid to Madrid, and there did preach ſomething at the Jeſuits Colledge at Madrid, (what it was I cannot tell) when Don John of Auſtria was by.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: If any of my Lords of the Council do remember it they may Teſtifie.

sp.speaker: L. Privy Seal.
sp.p: My Lords, I shall tell your Lordships as much as I remember of it: Dr. Oats was examined about his Journey into Spain, and (amongſt the reſt) ſome Queſtion hapned to be asked, whether he had ſeen Don John of Auſtria, he ſaid he had ſeen one that was called ſo, that he knew him not, but he was pointed to one that they ſaid was Don John of Auſtria; that I heard.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lord, I thank you.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: You hear what is ſaid, Dr. Oats.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, ſuppoſe I did ſay ſo, I think there is no crime in it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: 'Tis not objected againſt you as a Crime, but as a miſtake in your Oath, there was no ſuch man there.

sp.speaker: L. Privy Seal.
sp.p: My Lords, I would not be miſunderſtood in the Evidence I give; I did not ſay that Oats ſaid he knew him, but that he knew him not, and only was told ſuch a man was he.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: It was made apparent, that I did not know him, becauſe I miſtook his Perſon.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I do ſtand upon it, That upon his Oath, (and I have reaſon to believe he did ſo, becauſe I am ſo informed) he ſaid it was Don John of Auſtria.

sp.speaker: L. Privy Seal.
sp.p: No, my Lord, Dr. Oats ſaid he was a tall lean man, and it ſeems he was a little fat man.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: If any man would shew him a man to counterfeit Don John of Auſtria, he would not shew him a lean man for a fat.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Go on, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I shall now put your Lordships in mind that he ſwore, but my Memory is bad, and my Eyes much worſe, that he ſaw me receive a Commiſſion, and it ſeems he ſaw what it was too: Now it is ſtrange, that amongſt ſo many Commiſſions that were given, none should be extant; I deſire him to shew the Commiſſion he ſaw me receive.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Would your Lordship have him shew the Commiſſions which he ſaw you receive?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I do not believe he can shew my Commiſſion; for I am ſure there was none; I deſire him to shew any one of my Letters he talks of. He ſays, he came over, feigning to be a Papiſt, when he was not, and that they shewed him preſently all my Letters, and now he is come to diſcover the Plot; I ask him, did he keep any one of my Letters?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Have you any of any Lords Letters by you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, I could not keep any Letters ſent to the Fathers, I had a fight of them, but none of them to my particular uſe.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Does he know my Hand? did he ever ſee it in his life?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: Yes, I do know his Hand, I believe I have a Letter of my Lords by me, but not about me, 'tis of no Concern; I'm ſure I have one of my Lord Arundel's.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: But he ſays he hath a Letter of mine; let him shew one of my Letters.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: He writes a mixt Hand, I think 'tis but an indifferent one.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: So many Comiſſions, and ſo many Letters, as are ſpoken of, and not one to be found or produced.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Can you ſend for the Letter?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, I am not certain of that.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Where did you ſee my Lord write?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: At Fenwick's, my Lords, when I carried the Letter to the Poſt.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: How often hath he ſeen me at Fenwick's?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, not above twice, if twice.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I cannot ſay I did not ſee him there, but I can ſay I don't know the place, nor that ever I was there.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, will his Lordship ſay I never ſaw him at Dr. Perrots?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lord Stafford.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Where did he live?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: In Dukes-ſtreet, going into Lincolns-Inn-Fields; he is the Arch-Prieſt of the Seculars, that is, the Principal of the Secular Clergy; and he hath the care of the Engliſh Colledge for the ſending of Scholars to the Colledge. Mr. Fiſher, my Lord Stafford, and Dr. Perrot were together diſcourſing about ſending his Son thither, and Mr. Fiſher would have one ſent with him that was Dr. Perrot's Man.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I do profeſs before God, I was never at Dr. Perrot's in my whole life.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did not you ſend your Son abroad?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: No, my Lords, not I.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Had he a Servant at Dr. Perrot's to attend him?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: No, my Lords, not that I know of, I cannot ſay he had not.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I tell you poſitively, as I am a Chriſtian, my Lords, I did not ſend my Son to Lisbon, he went againſt my Will. I told him I had an averſion to it, but ſaid I will not lay my Commands on you not to go, but he would go, I could not help it; I told him, Do you mean to go into the Colledge? he would not tell me.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, does not your Lordship know Dr. Perrot? Lord Stafford, Yes, my Lords, I do.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Were you never with him at his Houſe in Duke-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: No, my Lords, never in my life, nor ſaw that Fiſher he ſpeaks of, ever in my life.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, 'tis againſt the Rules of that Houſe, that any be admitted of that Houſe (if their Parents be Catholicks) without conſent of their Parents.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: If he be admitted there, I know it not.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: He lives there.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: But I proteſt before God, my Lords, I asked him that Queſtion, Will you go to the Colledge? No, ſays he, I will go to lie at the Bishops Houſe; but as for Dr. Perrot, I never was at his Lodgings in my life, and I never knew where he lay; he hath been with me ſometimes, but I knew not that he was a Doctor. But, my Lords, I deſire I may not be ran down by theſe Fellows, who do not ſpeak a word true, nor one tittle. My Lords I have Witneſſes in whoſe Houſe Fenwick lay. Call them and ask them if ever they knew me in their lives.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What kind of man was he?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, he is an ancient man he wears his own Hair.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Is he a tall man, or a low man?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: A luſty man.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Truly, my Lords, I never was at his houſe ſince I was born.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, I'll tell your Lordships a Circumſtance, That Summer Don Franciſco de Melos, the Ambaſſador here was ſick, and I think he died of the Sickneſs, Dr. Perrot was his Father Confeſſor; I was waiting for Dr. Perrot ſome time, for he promiſed to meet me at his Lodgings, and this Gentleman the Priſoner at the Bar did come in there.

sp.speaker: L. Staffo rd.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: Into Dr. Perrot's Lodging. Dr. Perrot had a Kinſman there that waited on him; and when my Lord came in, he was in haſte to ſpeak with Dr. Perrot, and he offered me half a Crown to fetch Dr. Perrot to him, and I made him this Reply, I was no Porter.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p:
If ever I ſaw this man in my life ſince I was born, or heard of
his Name till the Plot, then I will confeſs my ſelf guilty of all. Indeed, when firſt I heard of the Plot (they ſaid) there was one Mr. Oats diſcovered it, but I did not know any ſuch man.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: I went by another Name, and went in another Habit, and my Lord Stafford, though his memory be bad, yet it can't be ſo bad, but that he muſt remember ſomething of me.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I don't remember you, I never ſaw your face in my life.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: You would have given him half a Crown to have fetch'd Dr. Perrot.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: It ſeems then at that time, I took him for a poor Fellow, that I should offer him a shilling or two.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: It is like I was, but I refuſed your half Crown, and told you I was no Porter.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I shall give you Evidence that he was a poor Fellow, ſince he gives me occaſion to prove it, nay, that he was ſo poor, that he was brought down to accept of 6 d. I will prove it by the party that gave it, now he puts me upon it: But, my Lords, this Doctor Oats ſays he ſaw ſome of my Letters, I deſire to know what was in them; Did he take any Notes? What was in them?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you when you had a ſight of theſe Letters at St. Omers, take any Notes out of them?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats
sp.p: What Notes I did take, if I did take any, I have not now in being, but I do not remember that I did take any. Beſides, my Lords, we could keep no Papers by us, but what we communicated to our Superiours, and therefore it was ſtill their care to look after their Papers themſelves; and in that Circumſtance of time, if they had known I had taken Notes out of their Papers, it would have been prejudicial to me, and indangered my life.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p:
My Lords, I infer this one thing further, upon what this Doctor Oats tells you, He did ſeemingly profeſs himſelf of the Catholick Religion, and I do ſtand upon it, that hereupon he is no competent Witneſs in that which he offers againſt me: For he being of the Church of England, (for I think he profeſſes himſelf ſo, and wears that Habit) I ſay, any man, let him be who he will in the world, Church of England man or other, that shall pretend himſelf to be a Papiſt, for what end ſoever it be that he ſo pretends, and diſſembles with God Almighty, which he muſt do to a great height, in receiving that Sacrament, which is by your Lordships and the Houſe of Commons declared to be groſs Idolatry, is not eaſily to be eſteemed a Witneſs. I appeal to your Lordships, to the Houſe of Commons, and every body, whether ſuch a Fellow, that will abhor his Religion, let him do it for any ends in the world, be a man to be credited; and eſpecially ingaging in ſuch a way, to ſuch an height, in that which his Conſcience tells him is idolatrous, is not a perjured Fellow, and no compleat Witneſs? No Chriſtian, but a Devil, and a Witneſs for the Devil. And I appeal to the
whole Chriſtian World, if a Proteſtant of the Church of England should come to be a Servant to a Catholick and pretend himſelf a Papiſt, and were not ſo, whether he were fit to be countenanced; as it did once happen to me at Bruſſels, fore the King came in, one that was a Proteſtant came to be my Footman, and he profeſſed himſelf afterwards to be a Catholick; and when I found he was not ſo, I told him what a Villain he was, and he ought to be punished ſeverely. I deteſt ſuch diſſembling with God, and I think by the Laws of God and Man, and the Holy Scriptures, ſuch a perjured man is no Witneſs. I am ſorry I have troubled your Lordships ſo long. But now if you pleaſe to give me leave, my Lords, I will give you my Reaſons why I called him now: when I did remember how he had diſſembled with God Almighty, as I ſaid before, I did conſider with my ſelf, ſure this Dr. Oats muſt have been, ever ſince he hath returned, of a very ſevere, ſtrict and ſober life; for a man that hath ſo diſſembled with God, ought to shew himſelf of an exemplary, peaceful, pious, civil life, to teſtifie the truth and reality of his Repentance. But laſt night when I came home, and was ſiting by the fire ſide extreamly weary, my Daughter here comes in, and asks me if I had heard what had paſſed between Dr. Oats and the Lieutenant; how he called the Lieutenant Raſcal and Goaler: ſure then, ſaid I, to my ſelf, this is not the quiet, civil, ſober man, that ſuch a one that hath lived as he hath done, ought to be. And this is the reaſon I ſpeak of it, that he should call him vile Names, Goaler and Raſcal; it did not become a man of his Coat to do it: whether it was ſo or no, I do not know, but Mr. Lieutenant, I ſuppoſe, will ſatisfie your Lordships.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What did Oats ſay to you, Mr. Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Lieuten.
sp.p: My Lords I was deſiring Mr. Oats that he would keep the people down, becauſe there was a great croud; and ſeeing a great many people come in, he told me, they were Witneſſes that were to come in: ſaid I, I believe half of theſe are not Witneſſes; and the door opening ſo often, I could keep this place in no order; ſo I deſired they would ſtand away that were not Witneſſes: why, ſays he, you are but a Goaler; then I told him, if it were not for his Coat, and I were out of this place, I would break his head. Then he called me Raskal.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lord Steward, I deſire to know whether this be a Witneſs fit to be believed againſt any man.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Mr. Oats, this does not become you; 'tis very ill manners in you.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, the Lieutenant of the Tower hath the Law; and I refer my ſelf to the Law, if I have done him any wrong.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: It did not become Mr. Lieutenant of the Tower to tell him he would break his head.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lieutenant.
sp.p: Why? if any man out of the Court, or in another Habit, should tell me I was a Goaler, I think I should not deſerve to be the Kings Lieutenant, if I did not break his Head.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Pray tell the Court ſo. But yet, under favour, you ought not to threaten him for a word to break his head.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I do ſay this to your Lordships, a man that hath diſſembled with God Almighty in ſo high a nature, as he ackowledges himſelf to have done, ought to be a man of a very ſevere life afterwards, and not ſo paſſionate and cholerick, as it ſeems this fellow is.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Will your Lordship proceed?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: For this man, truly, I shall ſay no more; I think I have ſaid enough to make him appear a perſon not fit to be believed. I would only ask Stephen Dugdale a Queſtion, if you pleaſe; 'tis but a little, I won't hold you long. I only ask, and if he deny it, I'le prove it, whether he was not a Priſoner at Stafford for Debt, when he made the firſt Affidavit?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Were you a Priſoner for Debt at Stafford, when you made your firſt Affidavit?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: In the Serjeants hands I was, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. Staff.
sp.p: For a very great Debt, my Lords, ſome hundreds of pounds, and he was a fellow not worth a Groat: And, my Lords, Dr. Oats ſays I offered him half a Crown, and he refuſed it. I call Ellen Rigby to prove he was ſo poor he begg'd for ſix pence.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: I will ſave my Lord the trouble of proving any ſuch thing. My Lord Stafford ſays I was a poor man, and had not ſix pence in my pocket; I can make it appear to the Houſe of Lords, that ſometime ſince I came in upon this Diſcovery, I have not had two pence in my pocket, and ſometimes I have not had ſix pence: but a mans Pȯverty is no objection againſt his Honeſty.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Where is Ellen Rigby to prove, whether she did not give him ſix pence? But then, my Lords, pray ask him whether he did not ſwear at a former Tryal, he had ſpent ſix or ſeven hundred pounds more than he got?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you ſay at a former Tryal, you were five or ſix hundred pound out of purſe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: My Lords, I will ſatisfie this Houſe what I ſaid; what folks write after me, I am not to juſtifie. But, my Lords, I had a Friend of mine preſented me with 100 l. I name not his Name; but if that be queſtioned, he is a Peer of this Houſe, and will juſtifie it. I had 100 l. for my Narrative. I had 100 l. for taking ſome Jeſuits; which is 300 l. I had for ſome other Copies that I printed, a matter of 50 or 60 l. And now I can make it appear, that as to thoſe Sums which I received in groſs, I have ſpent them all, and more in this Service, for I have none of the money now by me.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He makes out but 350 l. and he ſwore he was out 700 l. but he does not ſwear one true tittle, nor is any whit to be believed.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: If you expect I should prove it, I can prove it now.

sp.speaker: Managers.
sp.p: Be quiet Dr. Oats, we will do you right anon.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I do not know for the preſent that I have any thing elſe to trouble your Lordships with. I remember theſe Gentlemen when I asked them if they had any more Evidence to give in, ſaid No, unleſs I should give them ſome occaſion; and now I deſire your Lordships, if they bring any new Evidence, that I may have time to anſwer it.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: God forbid but you should have liberty to anſwer any Objection.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, before we go about to ſum up our Evidence we shall have occaſion to call ſome Witneſſes, and that will be to fortifie what our Witneſſes have ſaid, to diſcover what kind of Witneſſes have been made uſe of againſt them, and to falſifie what my Lords Witneſſes have ſaid in ſome particulars. Theſe will be the three Heads for which we deſire to call Witneſſes. And becauſe (my Lords) we will not trouble you with making one intire Narration of what they can ſay, or to what purpoſe we call them before they come, we deſire the favour that we may acquaint your Lordships with it, ſtill as we call them; for that we think will be the way more clearly to be underſtood. My Lords, we shall begin to make good by other Witneſſes, ſome things ſaid by Mr. Dugdale, (for he was our firſt Witneſs, and therefore in order of time we will firſt begin with him.) My Lords, the Priſoner at the Bar was pleaſed to object—

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I would not interrupt him; but I would ask whether there were more than two heads that he proceeds upon to fortifie their own Evidence, and to falſifie mine.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, I think we may comprehend all under thoſe two heads: But, my Lords, you obſerve, one great matter my Lord did inſiſt upon yeſterday, was this. That he, it is true, hath ſeen Mr. Dugdale at my Lord Aſton's (though by the way I muſt ſay this, my Lord at the firſt did not ſeem to know him.)—

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I did not know him in his Peraiwig.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do not interrupt them, my Lord, for they muſt have the ſame liberty that you had, to go on without interruption.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p:
We muſt have the ſame freedom my Lord had. I will do his Lordship that right, he did afterwards recollect himſelf, and ſay, His Perriwig had made that alteration in him, that he did not know him. But my Lord was alſo pleaſed to ſay yeſterday, That though he did know him, yet he looked upon him as ſo mean and inconſiderable a fellow, that he did purpoſely avoid all diſcourſe with him; and that ſometimes when he was a dry at my Lord Aſton's he would not ſpeak to him to help him, nor to call one to help him to drink. My Lord, was pleaſed yeſterday alſo to deny that ever he had any Converſe with him but only that one time, when indeed Mr. Dugdale did deſire to make uſe of my Lord, that by his interpoſition he might have leave to go to the Foot-Race. My Lords, your Lordships very well perceive we are now going about to prove a matter moſtly ariſing within my Lord Aſton's Family; and what Witneſſes we shall have from thence, your Lordships may eaſily imagine will not be very favourable to us: and if
we have not many to this point, your Lordships will take into conſideration, that thoſe who can give the fulleſt proof here, muſt be thoſe of the Family, and the Religion of the Family. But, my Lords, we will call one or two that I believe will give you ſatisfaction that my Lord the Priſoner was no ſuch ſtranger to Mr. Dugdale; that they have been ſeen together, and alone together; and that is the firſt thing we deſire to call Witneſſes to. Call Mr. Anſell and William Hanſon.

div.p: Mr. Hanſon was ſworn.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Where do you live? Whoſe Servant are you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: At Wilnal in Stafford ſhire.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: I deſire, if you be ſatisfied where he lives, that he will tell you whether he hath been at my Lord Aſton's, and ſeen my Lord Stafford there.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: Have you ſeen my Lord Stafford at my Lord Aſton's?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: A little above two years ago.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Be pleaſed he may name the time poſitively.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: My Lord Stafford is not ſo well verſed in proſecutions of this nature, as to know that he is not to interrupt us while we are examining our Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: My Lord, your Lordship received no interruption, nor muſt give none.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, we deſire this Witneſs may be asked, whether or no he hath ſeen Mr. Dugdale and my Lord Stafford at any time together.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, my Lords.

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: When, and where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I cannot juſtly tell the time.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Can you tell the place?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, at my Lord Aſton's.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Whereabouts?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: In my Lord Aſton's Parlour.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: And were they alone?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Mr. Dugdale fetched me to my Lord Stafford.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: And was no body in the Parlour when Dugdale fetched you to my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: No, my Lords, I think there was not.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: He thinks there was not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: There was not, to my beſt remembrance.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, will you be pleaſed to ask him the Occaſion why Dugdale fetched him to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: My Lord had a mind to have a Boy,

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: What was the occaſion that Dugdale did come to fetch you to my Lord Stafford in the Parlour?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: To bring the Boy, my Lords, Yong Hawkins. Mr. Dugdale fetched me and the Boy to him; it was a Boy that my Lord would have to live with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: Can you tell what time of the year it was? whether Winter or Summer as near as you can?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Aye, What time of the year was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lords, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: I deſire to ask him, whether, when he went away, he left them together?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you leave them together?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: To my beſt remembrance, my Lords, I did. The Boy and I went away together, and we left them at my Lord Aſton's Parlour-door.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: Call James Anſel.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Nay, if you have done with him, my Lord Stafford may ask him any Queſtions.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I shall tell you how this thing is. There was a report that this Hawkins was a very good running Foot-boy; and this was ſpoken of at my Lord Aſton ▪s at Dinner or Supper, I don't know which, nay ſeverall times about that time; it was when my Lord of Danby was Treaſurer, and his Son my Lord Dunblain was much for Foot-matches, and I had a minde to have a Foot-boy to make a match with him; and I believe Dugdale at Dinner or Supper did ſay that he was a good running Lad, and I might deſire to ſee him, and Dugdale did bring him to me I believe into my Lord Aſton's Parlour; but there was at leaſt ſix or ſeven in the Room beſides.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: My Lord Stafford, Was this at that time when your Lordship was at Tixal the 12 of September?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Pray, my Lords I deſire to ask him that Queſtion; I would know what year it was.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: He ſays it was above two years ago,

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I profeſs I believe it was one or two years before I was taxed with this Plot. I did never think I should be queſtioned about this, or I could eaſily have brought witneſſes that were by at that time. It is true he did come to me, but pray what time of day was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: In the morning I think it was.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: I profeſs to God, it was after Supper; as I hope to be ſaved, it was as we were going to bed, to the beſt of my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: Did you come into the Parlour after Supper?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I am not ſure what time it was.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: If his Lordship pleaſe to ask him any more Queſtions, if not, we will call another. James Anſell. (who was ſworn.)

sp.speaker: L. H. Steward.
sp.p: What is your Name?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: James Anſell.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Where do you live?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: At Heywood in Staffordshire.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you live with my Lord Aſton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: I have been at my Lords Houſe at Tixal.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: But you are not of the Family?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: How far is Heywood from Tixal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: A Mile.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Have you ſeen my Lord Stafford at Tixal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: I have ſeen a man they called my Lord Stafford. I did not know him, but as they told me.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee Dugdale in the company of a man they called my Lord Stafford?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: Two years ago I was at Tixal, and there I ſaw one that they ſaid was my Lord Stafford walking with Mr. Dugdale, whom I did know.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Where was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: In the Court at Tiaxl, walking together.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Were they alone? Was there no body elſe in company?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: None that I ſaw; there might be more company, but I ſaw no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: Pray, my Lords, ask how long ago this was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: About Summer was two years.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: If his Lordship will ask him any Queſtions now we have done, he may; otherwiſe we will call another.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: My Lords, I have recollected my ſelf as well as I can in ſo short a time, and all I can ſay is, ſome of my Servants were by, I ſuppoſe; and I do aſſure your Lordships, the other buſineſs was above three years ago; ſo the fellow does not know what he does ſay.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Will you ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Pray ask him how long he ſaw me in the Court with Dugdale.

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: How long was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: I cannot tell. I did but walk through the Court: I came to ſpeak with Mr. Dugdale, and he was with my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Stafford.
sp.p: Did he hear us diſcourſe, or any word we ſaid?

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Jones.
sp.p: My Lords, if you pleaſe, before Anſell go away, we would ask him a Queſtion to another point; and that is, For what reaſon Dugdale was ſecured, whether he went away for Debt or no?

sp.speaker: L. H. Stew.
sp.p: Do you know wherefore Dugdale was ſecured, or why he went from my Lord Aſtons.

sp.speaker: Mr. Anſell.
